Name: June132017

She definitely struck me as an ABF, but I can't cancel once I see the scowl or I will get DA'd for racism. Anyhoo, I'm pretty sure this one 4*'d me this morning.

Name: touberornottouber
Story:
I get a ride request to go to an apartment. When I arrive it shows me that it is a scheduled ride for 9:45 - 9:55. It is 9:46 so I message them to let them know i am in front of the building (there are 30 buildings in this complex and the GPS is often off). She messages back that she will need a couple minutes. I say "no problem" because I can live with 2-3 minutes. But then she messages back that she "uses the scheduled rides to give her some extra leeway". (she is thinking that she has until 9:55 to come out and is starting to get snooty with me). I consider messaging back to tell her, no, she misunderstood how it works but thought better of it as you never know how they will react. I also consider whether I should just cancel the ride then and there and leave to avoid having to deal with her but decide to let it go.

It finally tells me I can now cancel and get paid. I decide to wait an extra three minutes just to be a nice guy (I really am not a jerk honest). Finally I am over 8 minutes in now. It's 9:54 so I cancel.

She was going to wait to 9:55 to "show me" and make me wait for being "impatient". I wonder how that worked out for her? I drove away about $4.50 richer. Sorry lady but I ain't your butler and your ride was going to be a minimum fare. I am sure she was ont he phone with Uber. Hopefully they told her how it works but I doubt it.

Name: losiglow
Story:
I thought a thread dedicated to funny screenshots would make for a good laugh. These can be ones that show some crazy low pax rating, wacky pax messages through the app, funny notifications from Lyft or Uber or anything else that made you raise an eyebrow and you thought quick enough to screenshot it.


Here's one I had with the longest ping I've ever gotten. 34 minutes and probably 30 miles to pick up a pax. Yeah, I'll get right on that!  





Here's one where my AR and CR both plummeted to 0%. Good for the CR but wow. I didn't know I was turning down that many rides. Turns out it was a glitch of course. Returned to normal the next day.




Anyone getting these crazy long waits for scheduled rides lately? I've made a habit of checking beforehand because Uber will sometimes send me to a pax when there's as much as 30 minutes before their scheduled ride. Wow. Just wow. Needless to say, I cancelled with a "don't want to wait".

Name: Dr.Y
Story:
Hello all,
I drive in Chicago, and today I had someone named ozasee for a ride. I discovered he wasn't wearing a mask, and refused to put one on. Once he did, it was under his chin, and I repeatedly asked him to put it on. He put it under his nose, and started complaining about Chicago not having a mask mandate. I explained it was Uber's policy, and Chicago had nothing to do with it. He refused to put it on, so I pulled over to a gas station, and ended the ride. He then refused to get out of the car, and I had to call the police. This is how my day started today. His pickup location was . He was verbally abusive about getting out of the car, and wouldn't get out. Uber sent him a message reminding him about the mask, and he will have to prove with a photo that he's wearing a mask before getting a ride. Nothing about him being rude or anything from Uber. Stupid useless people in that company. Just be warned about this person named ozasee in Chicago.

Name: Benjamin M
Story:
As some know here, I decided to go and get a "real job" like my wife had been "suggesting".

"You know, a W-2. No, I don't care if you don't want to flip burgers! 

Well, I thought that I was doing pretty well driving Uber (after expenses, still about what I earned as a paramedic) but my 2018 Civic hit 70k and gas prices are through the roof.

So, "real job".

Back to EMS? Still a maybe. But I'm not in my 20s anymore, a touch of PTSD, and two hernias.

Back to programming? Competitive, also for the young, and I do not want to be behind a desk.

Law enforcement? That was on my horizon before we moved to the big city and "stuff" happened.

So, one night, I decided to send a Facebook message to a limousine company that I first noticed before I started rideshare full time, brand new to the city life. Instant reply, I was hired on the spot two days later.

First vehicle I drove was a Chrysler 300. Brakes were shot. Second, another 300, tires were bald and one had an enormous chunk of rubber missing.

Soul searched for about three days (and posted here). Decided to give them the benefit of doubt, just as I would want, emailed them basically saying that they are awesome but I can't drive unsafe shit.

Owner's girlfriend stepped in, took care of everything like a boss, and I am now driving their best. The pandemic nearly killed their business, that section of the fleet is just now becoming more in demand.

Now, Winifred. She had just become a regular when I started - very "well to do". First trip was from an independent care facility (now assisted living unit, she's not happy) to the afternoon Mass.

I was warned in advance (and given a salute by her last driver) before I headed to pick her up - third trip for the company. Very demanding pax and she needs a lot of help getting in and out of the car.

She asked me to do five things at once, said she's old enough to be my grandmother (Mom's her age), AC was either too hot or too cold, and made me pull over to find the right radio station. All in the first five minutes 😂

First time waiting for a pax on the job. People were commenting on the fancy car parked by the door to the church. It was her first Mass since the pandemic began.

After I got her situated in the car again, she started to apologize for how she acted before. I cut her off. Told her that I know chronic pain when I see it (arthritic, obese) and how it can definitely **** with your mood. And I told her to stop calling herself old.

Dropped her off, called the company, and told them that if Winifred ever needs a ride to PLEASE let me know. And she requested me for her next trip.

Mass again yesterday, this time I joined her. Boss asked if we needed to charge extra for an escort. 😂

And that's my Sunday moving forward. Paid a decent amount to drive a friend (Winifred said I'd better not think of her as a pax) to church and back.

Oh, and here I am picking up her phone off of the road yesterday because I put it on the roof and forgot. Not a scratch. Divine intervention??😳




Rideshare has been either extremely profitable here or less than minimum wage, just seems to be how the wind blows. Tips are pretty much unheard of, pick up distance is still pretty high for most pings. Pax are still left stranded at our airport.

Even though I'm not totally down with it (seems a bit low), I earn $10/hr from when I leave the "garage" (that can be home if the car isn't needed before or between trips) until I return.

unlike Uber and Lyft, tips are included, minimum of 18% - and many fares are $200+. So, no dead miles and no expenses. Lately driving a 2019 Lincoln MKT, 2017 Continental, 2019 Suburban, and soon a 2020 Continental.

Pax run the gamut, from Winifred to newlyweds, executives, flight crews (airport to hotel and back), organ transplant teams, and - last week - a show creator for AMC followed by his lead actor.

I was star struck enough, then had the surreal experience of the main man behind the show asking me to stop so he could literally run a block to an ATM so he could tip me $20 cash (in addition to the $20 or so included, short airport run).

In conclusion, companies like this are hiring. "Oh, rideshare drivers are un employable" - bullshit. I submitted a resume, showed up on time wearing a suit, "here's where the keys are, water bottles are over there, when can you start" - that was the interview.

So, if you are burnt out being an "ant" (hate that term but whatever), consider the option. And I'm part time for now, still "anting" on and off.

My theme song right now -

Police said they found Raquel Spohn Wehber, 58, in her car near a neighborhood market with multiple stab wounds last Tuesday. 

How do you like this story?




I felt unsafe couple of time with female passengers on the back who were fooling around while I drove them. Nothing bad happen though. But new generation have no respect to anything.

Name: touberornottouber
Story:
I get a request for a 7 minute trip on Uber to pick up at Chipotle. I get there and the place is deserted (I don't think it was actually open yet) save for a man sitting at one of the outside tables. The guy looked a bit poor -- like your normal lower class service worker here really.

The guy gets in and immediately slams my door but apologizes right away. Fair play I think to myself. At least he apologized. He ended up being a pretty good passenger and he asked me a lot about Uber. I think this might have been his first Uber ride.

At the destination I end the trip and explain that it should pop up on his phone in a minute or so with a record of the trip and what it cost. About 30 seconds later he tells me that he tipped me $10 and would have tipped more but that was the most they would allow. :/

It occurs to me that this gig would be very different if every passenger tipped like him. Also don't judge a book by the cover. Sometimes what looks like a bad trip can actually end up being really good. I get the feeling the guy tried to tip me $20.

Name: June132017
Story:
I figured it wasn't worth doing. Probably 10 mins to get there and 15 mins to get out of the concert traffic. I figured people would understand to tip. So I did an experiment and see if they would tip. Nope. Both rides didn't tip yet. 

Then some random guy tips $5 on a 10 minute ride not involving the concert. Lol, you can't make this stuff up. 

$5 was what I was looking for the concert traffic. $10 for generous tippers in the concert traffic. Maybe $20 if they wanted to really tip.

Name: June132017
Story:
I guess these renters didn't pay rent for a while. So the guy there was pretty nice and asked me if he could put all this junk and an air conditioner in the trunk. "Sure, why not?" 

So he loaded up the trunk with trash bags full on items. Luckily he closes the trunk nicely after a few attempts. So then a kid and the 2 adults get in the car. 25 miles away to Day's Inn we go. 10 mins for them to unload there. Metal silverware starts piercing the bags and falling to the cement. In my mind: "yep, this verifies the eviction ride theory." 

At least they realized I cut them a break because at first I was saying I didn't want alot of stuff in my car. They seemed very grateful which was nice.

Name: FLKeys
Story:
Got an invitation to accompany a lady to her room. In this case it was a bungalow. I politely declined and moved about my evening. She was attractive, and a little tipsy. Wouldn't say drunk, but definitely feeling the buzz.

Just got a voice mail from her, thanks for giving my number out Uber. She left her sandals under my passenger side front seat, could I kindly bring them to Bungalow 8 tonight between 8 and 9 PM. Call her if I have any questions. the number she left matches the number she called from, so not an Uber line. Ran out to my car and sure enough there are a pair of sandals wedged under the seat.

When I leave at work tonight and drive by the resort I will be leaving the sandals with the front desk and the instructions to deliver them between 8 & 9 PM. Let them deal with it.

This is my 3rd offer in just over 3 years. Hope it is my last.

Name: Cvillegordo
Story: I've been driving in the Charlottesville Virginia area since the fall of 2019. I have taken rides to Richmond Harrisonburg and Stanton and picked up rides in those areas on the way back. I've also gone as far North as Culpeper but did not get any pings on the way back from there. My understanding has always been that if I were to take a longer trip for example to Dulles airport, that I could set my destination to return and possibly get trips along the way. I have never done this because it doesn't seem to make sense financially, Is too much time and too many dead miles. I've always assumed that I'm not authorized to drive in that area, other than in a return situation. Yesterday I had a conversation with support about my annual inspection. I uploaded the new certificate and they did not automatically lift the hold; I had to call them. After the rep helps me out she did confirm that my area includes anywhere in Virginia. She also said that if I can go online that means I can get trips. My wife and I are in NoVA, DC and Maryland 2 to 4 days a week for her work. I always play with the app to look at surges and so forth, and I have always been able to go online in those areas; I haven't tried to actually take trips or pings simply because I've never been in my car, I'm always in my wife's company car but theoretically I COULD take my car, I spend 4-8 hours amusing myself while she works, the idea is tempting, except for the problem of putting huge miles on my car just for a few bucks.. Support has told me quite a number of incorrect things in the past so is this person correct or is this person confused? Is it true that if you can go online, you will get pings? When my inspection was expired for the last several days, I could still go online - I just wasn't getting any pings. So that tends to refute the information that support told me already. Thoughts?

Name: June132017
Story: Once on Monday and once on Wednesday. I got $3 out of the Wed. cancel while in route. Thoughts?

Name: FLKeys
Story:
Well not really Urine, however the PAX should not have lied.

I get to a pick-up and there is a guy and girl in bathing suites. She is wrapped in a beach towel, he does not have one. Doors are locked, I roll down window and ask are you wet, you can't get in if you are wet. If you are still wet I have extra towels in the back. Guy replies no they are not wet. I repeat I have extra towels in the back you can sit on. He says no we are not wet. 

I open the doors and they get in. Take them several miles to a resort. Talk about how people want to get in while wet and I can't drive anymore until my seats dry. She gets out and her towel falls off, okay string bikini the size of yarn explains why she was wrapped up in a towel. I pull away and decided I better check the seat behind me. Idiot lied, I could clearly see where his bathing suit was wet and left my seat wet.

I turn the app off, take pictures and send in a urine complaint to Uber, after all he said he was not wet so he must have pissed his pants.

Took about two hours for Uber to respond along with $10 for cleaning fee and 5 extra Uber Pro points would be added to my total. Replied back that I had to have my seat cleaned as he pissed in it and they replied back that rider claimed his bathing suite must have been wet from swimming. I replied back with the conversation I had with the rider and also uploaded the video and sent them a link. Explained the video clearly shows he said he was not wet. After some back and forth for two days now Uber finally sent me another $70 for a total of $80.

And what is up with the 5 extra Uber Pro points? Told them I had no use for the Uber Pro Points. The never responded to that.

Name: _Tron_
Story:
For anyone doing Eats profitably I say more power to you.

But I can't fathom why anyone would use this service. As a user of the Uber rider app, I have been getting deluged with emailed coupons to try Eats "for free". But free doesn't include the many many ancillary charges like service fees. First I tried to use a $30 coupon and got this:







Then I tried a $25 coupon and ordered $19 worth of food. With all the extra chargers the meal was going to be $15 out of pocket. None the less I ordered with a 15% tip up front. Was given a nearly 2-hour delivery window. Two hours later the order was cancelled on a "your order could not be delivered" error.

Tried the $25 coupon again for $26 of food. The free meal was going to cost nearly $10. Coupon or no coupon the misc chargers are hilarious:





"Delivery fee"? Service fee"?? "CA Driver benefits fee"??? And on top of that a tip charge that defaults to 15%.

No thank you.

Name: The Jax
Story:
I was doing food delivery that day and stopped at Wawa to grab some things to eat and drink in between orders.

I am in line and there is this middle ages black guy in front of me. In front of him was this overweight guy. As the overweight customer is getting rung up, he all of a sudden went on some kind of fart storm. Like if you ate a lot of chili with beans in it and you just have a lot of gas with no expectation of using the bathroom. Just pressure and air.

So it basically went like this.....
<loud fart sound then stops>
"Oh god sorry i'm really sorry"
<more fart sounds after that then stop>
"Oh geez I am really sorry like oh my <fart sound> god"
<more farting>

The black guy in front of me turns around with such a disgusted look on his face like he was in the car driving past the sewage treatment plant on a hot day with the windows down.

Then he speaks LOUDLY while also using his hands in an explaining way....
<black guy voice with actual tactful pausing>
"You know... it smells like... someone is taking a poop... right here...
<points down with two fingers>
Like... I am standing in the bathroom stall... right next to the guy... who has food poisoning... and taking a massive diarrhea dump"

I busted out laughing so hard I had to grab the chip rack to keep me from falling. The entire store was laughing hysterically. The farting guy left real fast all embarrassed. It did stink in that general area from the farts. When the black guy gets up to the counter to pay, a woman behind me walks past me and offers to pay and thanks him for making her laugh so hard it made her day.

I guess I mean it was sad for the farting guy but the entire situation itself was funny. I wish that black guy was on TV like doing stand up. What a funny guy. He played it straight right after that, just kinda looking at everyone like come on now, this guy. Haha!!

Name: _Tron_
Story:
Uber badly wants me to drive again. It keeps sending incentive notices to my inbox. So as it happens I have been driving. Since last in the saddle I have lost Gold status, and my ability to see the destination of a ride request is now based upon the newish accepting 5 of 10 ride requests algo.

On the surface, the 5-of-10 algo seems to me like a halfway decent compromise, giving drivers up front details if they simply maintain a 50% acceptance rate. Of course drivers who accept a smaller percentage of rides will note that the low pay makes the 5-of-10 algo a joke. But even in my locale, where Uber still pays 98 cents a mile and 17 cents a minute, the 5-of-10 algo is a clown act. As anyone who has focused on the algo knows, acceptance rate is based upon each individual ride request, rather than on passenger request.

The downside of this nuanced difference played out for me yesterday with "Darren". Darren wanted a ride. Badly. His request for a long ride on the Lyft platform came to me, and I declined it. For my own good reasons I was unable to accommodate a pax who wanted a ride out of town. After all, I am an Independent Contractor and it is my right to choose which rides work for me. Darren then came in on the Uber app, which I also declined, lowering my 9 of 10 acceptance rate one notch. Undaunted, for the next half hour Darren toggled back and forth between platforms, requesting his out-of-town ride.

Uber, in all its wisdom, kept sending me Darren's requests. The algo was too dumb to realize that if I turned the request down once, nothing was going to change 5 minutes later. But the requests kept coming, and I noticed my acceptance rate was dropping with each successive decline. Finally, while on another ride, Darren's request came in again. Only this time there was no destination. I didn't realize the request was from stubborn Darren, and stupidly accepted it.

I drive the 10 minutes to the pickup point, then down a 1/4 mile dirt road, which cakes the back of my freshly washed car with dust, only to realize after starting the ride that my pax was the now infamous Darren. "Darren, I'm so sorry. I can't drive you to xxx. I know there's not a lot of Uber cars on duty right now (being that a lot of drivers are still preferring UI) but I just can't do it". Darren, whose family is just starting up a pot farm, replies in a most mellow way that it is totally cool, and to just drop him back to his pickup location. I do and move on.

Uber. Dude. I just want a reasonable driving experience. Anything less than that and you are de-incentivizing me. Get it?






And by the way, cancelling 2 out of 96 rides is a 2.13% cancellation rate. Not the 3% you are showing on my account.

Name: losiglow
Story:
You'd think he'd get free Uber rides for life. But he resorts to Lyft? What does this tell you? 

At least he ordered a Lux and tipped well. He didn't look like his normal self. Pale white, heavy set and short. But still.....

Name: FLKeys
Story:
Sunday evening I ended a trip. My next trip immediately popped up. I must have been tired, I don't remember accepting a stacked ping. Oh well it was a mile away and I headed that way. Later that evening I had another stacked trip that I did not recall taking. Did the trip. When it ended there was another stacked trip. Okay I know I'm not losing my mind and accepting trips without remembering it.

This time before I arrived to that pick-up I hit stop new requests. After that drop off I went to see what I was being paid for each trip. Basically looking for a surge. No surge to be had. Screen also did not show any surge zones. Went back online and immediately received a ping. After starting that trip I got a ping for a stacked ride. Accepted it. Dropped of PAX and headed to next pick-up. Started that trip, no ping for a stacked trip. Ended that ride and sure enough had another ping auto added. Hit last ride. Finished the final trip and said screw it, Uber to cheap to be charging and paying a surge, I went home.

Name: ANT 7
Story:
We've had 36-38 degrees celcius non-stop for a week now. Nornal temps for us are in the mid 20's at this time of year. It's dry here, so think "hot" like Palm Springs in July. I'm driving with the AC on for 10-11 hours straight.

Averaging 2-4 bus stop pick ups every day so far. Just like winter when it is -30 and people won't wait. Tips are great as my AC is ice cold.

What do you guys in the southern US do ? I cannot image driving down there.

Name: Guido-TheKillerPimp
Story:
Pick up Aisha.
Seems nice as we exchange pleasantries.
Aisha begins conversation on speakerphone with her friend.
Tells her about her wedding planned for new years eve... yadda yadda yadda.
Aisha thens begins discussing cost and such and how she is ONLY budgeting $100,000 for a wedding of 200 guests. WTF!!!
I almost drove into a ditch upon hearing that.
Drop off at her hotel. Thanks. Bye.
PS: Aisha did NOT budget a penny towards giving me a tip

Name: FLKeys
Story:
How many drivers have picked up someone running from the police? Knowingly or unknowingly at first?

I have never knowingly picked up anyone running for the police.

Last night I picked up my third one that I unknowingly at first picked up and latter realized they were running from the police.

Each of my 3 pick-ups had different out comes.

Name: June132017
Story: One thing I don't like about this gig is weirdo's ordering rides. People who wear hoodies and it's hot out is one example.

Name: Cvillegordo
Story: We have been having promotions every day, $6 per ride, so our small downtown area where the promotion applies is flooded with drivers. You can sit around and wait for one of the promo rides, or, if you want to make money, you can take what comes your way and hopefully a few of the very short $10 rides will come your way as well. Yesterday I took a 20 minute pick up at our airport for a 20 minute ride. Normally and especially during these promotions I get in touch with the rider and make sure that he is coming back towards the downtown area. 90% of the time that would be the case; if they say they're going North or West towards Harrisonburg I would probably cancel. I don't want to end up 45 minutes away from the downtown area and possibly deadhead all the way back. In this case I got no answer on my text, and assuming that the guy was probably waiting for his bag or just on the phone I went ahead to the pick up anyway. Surprise! Going north to Ruckersville. S.hit!! Oh well. Took him home, $22 ride and $5 tip, OK. Set destination back to downtown and luckily got two trips along the return, one short and one all the way back downtown. Both of these tipped, feeling lucky and good at this point. Then I got the phone call. My airport passenger thinks he left his phone in my car. I look around the back and there it is under the seat on the side where he dropped it. (His girlfriend is smoking hot, and not shy by the way. Kids, this is why you should lock your phones.) So I made the honest and well intentioned mistake of telling him that I found it. This nice guy with the hot girlfriend immediately turned into an entitled jerk and demanded that I return "my property!" to him at his house, which is now more than 45 minutes away from my location. At this point I had already accepted another trip so I told him to call me back in half an hour. A few minutes later I got in touch with support and they confirmed to me that since I had informed the passenger and Uber that I found his property, I was now obligated to return it to him. Good Lord, what a freaking nightmare. Surge popping up on top of the promotion in the downtown area, it's heating up as people are starting to return to their hotels and homes from going out to eat, I'm going to miss making some really good money if I drive all the way out to this dude's house again. He calls me again for the 4th time. He is getting upset and is very pushy, continues to demand that I drive to his home and return his property. I push my luck and fib; tell him that I cannot possibly drive all the way to Ruckersville as "I'm at the end of my shift." After a near meltdown he acquiesces and agrees to meet me half way. I suggest Walmart and he finally agrees. Walmart is fortunately much farther for him than for me, so I came out OK on this. Drove to Walmart did a little shopping, met the guy in front, returned his phone and he didn't say a word; no "thank you!" nothing. What a jerk, and lesson learned; never again will I admit to finding a phone from a distant drop off and never again will I drop anyone off at a distance without thoroughly checking around the back seat. After over 5,000 trips I know better, this was a stupid mistake. But I got my $15 returned item fee, and after another long talk with support they also added a bonus $6 promotion to my account.

Name: BallinBruha
Story:
Strolled into my regular McDonalds to pick up a delivery and the manager said they accidentally made an extra McFlurry for my customer and asked if I wanted it. I don’t usually eat very much dairy or sugar but this was essentially the delivery mans dream trip... FREE food ... I couldn’t pass it up and quickly downed it en route to my next delivery.... 1/2 later I was at home on the pot where I remained for the next 3 hours. 

Be careful out there ... anyone else got any free food tales/nightmares ?

Name: Illini
Story:
Accounting Contractor (AC): Hello! I'm here for the Accounting project you advertised for.
Major Corporation (MC): Great! We're delighted to have you join our community.
AC: I'm excited to be here and can't wait to start and contribute to your success. What exactly will I be doing?
MC Sorry, we won't tell you until you're at your desk and ready to work.
AC: What?? How will I know if I want to do the work?
MC: Once you start on the project, you can leave if you don't like the work. No worries, though, we'll call you back when we have a new project for you.
AC: Well that sucks, but OK. How much will I be paid for this project?
MC: We won't tell you until you complete the project.
AC: Let me get this straight --- you won't tell me what you want me to do until I accept your offer and be at my desk ready to work, AND you won't tell me how much you're paying me until after I'm done with the work.
MC: Hey, you're a smart one!
AC: This is absolute insanity. Good luck with your project. I'm outta here. Oh, and I hope your company goes bankrupt.

Story: Uber just approved my new insurance card in less than 5 minutes. Usually this is a multiple submit process. The picture I sent was kind of crappy, I fully expected them to kick it out.

Name: Haanjo
Story:
I picked up an Uber Eats order from a discount restaurant.

As I'm about to arrive at the customers apartment, a phone call comes in. I figure it's the customer who wants to give me special instructions to get to their place, so I answer.

Turns out it's the restaurant manager. He said he was not watching the front desk, and his employee forgot to give me the drinks that went with the order.

I tell him to refund the drinks, and I'm not coming back because I don't get paid to go back and deliver the drinks, and besides, it's his employee's responsibility to give me the correct order.

He tells me its between the customer and Uber, and its my responsibility to get the order right too. I tell him not only was his employee rude, but not to blame me for his employees mistake.

He tells me to tell the customer that I forgot his drinks. I tell him I'm done talking to him, to have a good night, and hang up the phone. At this point, I'm pretty irritated, and basically had already raised my voice when he blamed me for the mistake.

Yeah, I know, I could have checked for drinks, but when an employee hands me an order, I'm going to assume its correct. Every once in a while I do check orders for drinks, and occassionally I do catch errors, but I'm not going to waste my time and check the accuracy of orders everytime, especially if 97% of the time the orders are correct anyway, which is my satisfaction rate after this order.

What I didn't realize until I hung up, is that the restaurant can actually give you negative feedback, and when I checked my rating for deliveries, sure enough, the manager dinged me. Apparently the customer dinged me too...about 5 minutes after I checked my rating from the merchant, my customer satisfaction rating had dropped from 98% to 97%...which I suspect happened when the customer called the restaurant and the manager blamed me for the mistake.

Anyway, I came really close for telling the manager to F*** Off, so I'm glad I kept my cool. 

So, if you ever find yourself of the situation, first off, don't be an idiot like me and answer your phone like I did, and if you do answer the phone, be careful what you say to the store manager. Having said that, you aren't a store employee, and if they try to blame you for their employee screwing up, tell them to shove it, because at the end of the day, it's on them and not you.

Name: FLKeys
Story: Had an Uber Eats delivers last night, said leave at door. Start up the steps and see a glass door from top to bottom with blinds half up. Set food down and snap a picture. As I hit okay I catch the back ground. Couple going at it right in the middle of the living room. Glanced up and yeah they were going to town. Dang, close the blind if you re expecting a delivery. Oh well, they got dinner and I got a show.

Name: jfinks
Story: Typically businesses sell products for about 2.5x - 3x what they cost to make. Your car on average costs 57 cents per mile to operate. You should be selling that service for about $1.50 a mile on average.

Last night I took two very tipsy girls from one of the local college bars to their home out west of the city. I'm from that area, so I asked if they went to Meriwether Lewis Elementary, Henley M.S. and Western Albemarle H.S.

Hilarious answers; "Yes! And we STILL go to Western!"

There are underage kids by the thousands getting into bars with fake ID'S; typical fake ID'S these days are very good and can be nearly impossible to differentiate from genuine ID'S. Cracking down on that reality is clearly not a priority in a college town, although some years ago there was a large bust of a very sophisticated fake ID operation being run right in the heart of the fraternity area here in Charlottesville.

Story: I think Uber gouges third-parties...35 min ride made $83 bucks. It's happened before. I have a $36 surge last month.

Name: The super uber
Story: Here is the normal. The passenger takes forever to come out of the house. You begin taking them to their destination and they ask you if you could stop at the closest gas station ...they need to pick something up. Now this wasn't a stop that was put into the original request for a ride... it's sort of a quasi freebie. And then oh yes I will give you a decent tip. After an extended stop at the gas station we continue on to their destination. After arriving at destination they say.. could you please wait a minutes, I just need to do a few little things? Normally, coming out after 4 or 5 minutes we then proceed to go back to their original location but on the way they ask if you would mind stopping at a local all night food store, because they don't have any food at home. I say no and we proceed on to their final destination... time normally... about a half hour to 45 minutes especially at 2:00 or 3:00 in the morning. Now you wonder why quests are difficult to complete because of these situations.

Name: The super uber
Story: This past week. I lost income because riders claim that they never were picked up and that I picked up the wrong person. This is old stuff ...the easy way to get a free ride. I never pick up the wrong person always identifying each other before they get into the car. All BS... And you can't speak directly to an Uber person to talk about the situation so I've lost $10 in the last two weeks... they keep nipping away at me and giving free rides to people who don't deserve it. If they keep it up they're going to really lose their ass because right now we are teetering on the edge ....really on the edge. THE TIPPING POINT.

Name: Haanjo
Story:
Dear Ridershare Passengers,

When I'm waiting for you, I will wait 5 minutes. Not 5 minutes and one second. 5 minutes is 5 minutes. I only get paid roughly 12.5 cents per minute of wait time, and while I'm waiting for you, I'm missing out on other rides. 

And don't say you will tip me extra because often people who say that don't tip at all. For the record, sometimes I get paid more for cancelling the ride than I do for the ride itself, and keep in mind, I'm often parked in an odd spot waiting for you, sometimes blocking traffic, and sometimes dealing with drunk idiots who are trying to steal your ride.

And for the record, I understand that sometimes you need to pay your tab at the bar before you can leave. I get that. But you had a 15 minute notice for me to get there, while I was finishing up my last ride, plus another 5 minute notice while I was on my way to pick you up after dropping off my last passenger.

So, there is no excuse to not be waiting at the curb when I pull up. And for the record, when I started doing rideshare three and a half years ago, I used to bend over backwards for my passengers like you. But often, five minutes would turn into ten minutes, and when I bent over backwards for my passengers the most, you would be a bad passenger, things would go terribly wrong on the ride, and you would give me a one star rating for my efforts.

Over 11,000 rides later, I've learned from riders like you. 

When you say stuff like,

"Be right there",

What you really mean is that you are going to be late. And if I've been patient enough to wait for you for the entire 5 minutes and beyond, no, you can't smoke a cigarette before we leave...get in the freaking car!

So there you have it. I'd like to be a nice guy and wait, but you need to show some courtesy and respect for your driver, and not sit there and socialize with your friend up until the last possible second, because once I hit the gas pedal and start to take off, it's too late, and yelling at me to come back isn't going to change things.

And for the record, it took something like 8,000 rides with 800 late passengers to develop this attitude.  Bottom line is I'm not messing around anymore. So be ready!

Love, 

Your Driver............Vrrrooooooom!

Name: The super uber
Story:
Yesterday I received a No Reply email from Uber. I was told that I made an unauthorized passenger pickup at the airport. Uber has a parking area at the airport for drivers waiting for flyers looking for a ride. There is a pecking order. You must get in line and the driver with the longest wait time gets the next Uber request for a ride.
I had just dropped a rider and was on the highway out of the airport when a call came in requesting a ride at the airport. The fact that I got that call indicates that there were NO Uber drivers in the Que....waiting for potential
riders. I accepted the call, picked up the couple and took them to their destination. Here is my punishment...I will not be able to receive any ride requests to or from the Airport for 5 days. BooHoo. As an Uber driver, I had every right to return to the Airport to make that pickup. Uber is so fastidious about every rule and regulation, without regard to common sense.

Name: Guido-TheKillerPimp
Story:
Young Kim.
Where is he?
Where has he gone?
He seems to have vanished into thin air?
. What have you done to him?

Name: The super uber
Story:
Now driving for 5 years, I am on my 4th car. Ubering can be a dangerous job. My first 3 cars were destroyed by others making driving mistakes. Cars today are nothing but pieces of plastic. When you are hit, pieces fall off and insurance companies are quick to declare ...A total loss. In 2 cases, Uber insurance handled the accident. In the first I had a Uber passenger and in the second I was in route to pick up a rider. There was no medical involved. Uber's deductible is $1000 and mine is $500. My insurance sent me a check for $500. Now my 4th vehicle, a hybrid, 2016, I used in the winter months, trying to travel up steep hills covered in Ice and snow. The hybrid constantly shifted from gas to electric and back putting excessive  strain on the combustion engine. Bottom line, I burned out the engine,,,Kaput, Finito, gone. I had the car towed to the dealer to confirm my worst thought...the engine was DOA. The dealer mentioned that there was a recall on this particular model year...the bearings were wearing unnecessarily fast. The dealer contacted the Hyundai factory . . their email to the dealer was very short and sweet. GIVE THE CUSTOMER A NEW ENGINE...AT NO CHARGE.
Now I have a 2016 vehicle with 180,000 miles and a new engine. My total mileage, from pickup to drop off and drop off to pickup in 2020 was 156,000 miles.

Name: June132017
Story:
Some guy ordered a ride and the person I was suppose to pickup was 32 miles away. He somehow messed up and put in the wrong address. LOL, he said he was coming right out initially so I wound up waiting a couple minutes for him. He didn't tell me the ride was for someone else. I should have known because it was Lyft and the person on the screen wasn't near the pickup zone.

Anyway, he said he would compensate me for going there to pick them up. I said it's getting too late and this was my last ride. So I didn't go on a wild goose chase, but it probably would have been rather intresting. Intresting to see if I would have got paid good, or nothing, or in the middle.

Name: M62
Story:
Other drivers...

Many of us have had pax tell us that other drivers let them do stuff we didn't, like fitting 5 pax in a small car and the like.

What are some of the most common or best ones you've heard?

Name: #1husler
Story:
Pax have been holding court, talking smack and spilling the tea (so to say) about all the kinds of drivers they really don't like, and why they give one stars and complaints. 

Here are some most common categories pax seem to talk about:

1. The odd-ball. Sure, it goes without saying that RS would attract its share of society's outliers (ie, those who need to pay the bills but can't manage a W-2 gig), but some seem to take it one step beyond, to the point of turning off, or even freaking out pax. Stand out examples, according to pax, include one guy who had a pit bull riding shotgun (service dog? who knows???), a woman who kept addressing a male pax as "Martha" (even after he corrected her) and another lady who had the inside of her car decked out with pulsing disco lights. 

2. The maniac on the streets. Its one thing to drive like a "bat out of hell" to hustle to the drop off ASAP, but completely another to almost cause multiple accidents, get into an unsparring amount of altercations (both verbal and physical) with other drivers on the road until pax pleads to end the ride early and be let off at the nearest corner. Not good for "The Community"!

3. The slob. No pax likes getting into stranger's car which looks (and smells) like a junk yard. Even if their own car is that way or worse, they won't tolerate it when "Ubering" or "Lyfting"... pax complain the some drivers car get super gross, and they have roll the windows because of the funky odor....drivers grouse about pax eating in their cars, but a number of drivers (as reported by pax) are the one's munching away, with a sandwich and/or burrito in hand, while driving, food slipping everywhere. Clearly a one star ride there. 

4. The anti-social introvert. Many of us (yours truly included) remain open to talking shop with a pax, about this and that, to establish rapport to pull down a tip. So it's surprising how many drivers don't work that tip, and instead simply unlock the door, set the GPS and drive in total silence, arrive, unlock door, done...no greeting and welcome, confirmation of name and destination, "how's it going?" etc, nothing. And I'm not talking about members of the Deaf Community who are driving...I mean the folks who take the whole "our job is just to just to drive pax from point A to point B" ethos a bit too literally. One pax recounted how they get into the car, told her driver "good morning" and received a grunt as a response, followed by glowering stare through the mirror. She canceled the ride (I might have too). 

Do any of you fill into these groups?

Or?

Can anyone add to this list?

Name: June132017
Story:
Reflecting back on 4 years into the game, but is it? I took massive time off in 2020 due to the pandemic. Ride share requests had dropped dramatically in late March 2020. 

I would say the respect from my friends went way down since i've become a rideshare driver. I would say overall my happiness went way up though.

Moneywise I'd say this gig isn't worth it. I think we pay too much fixing our cars and putting gas into them. My previous job didn't pay that much though. So it's not like I left a $100K job for this, or something. Also, you don't get alot of time off doing rideshare. People don't respect rideshare drivers and we put alot of work into it. Honestly I can't say I blame them after taking a few rides from other drivers. 

Running into people I used to know was a pretty big highlight for me. I helped a friend go 90 miles down the road the one day. I guess not a friend, but someone who went to elementary school with me. It was weird he was literally 80 miles from the school we went to. Then months later, I ran into someone else I knew and we decided to have dinner. That was pretty cool and one of the few times I left the car. 

Another time some guys from a small town Illomois decided to make a stop at Wendy's and I was hungry too. Lol, we all had lunch together. Then just dropped them off at a theme park after we ate.

Name: jjanet167
Story:
As anyone expressed where Uber blocked their account without any reason? 
It‘s going 2wks now that my account has been blocked, I have called nd email with no luck. How long do I have to wait for someone from Uber to get back to me?

Name: dgates01
Story: What I want to know, are the drivers getting their usual chunk of that money or is it mostly going to corporate?

Name: Cvillegordo
Story:
Picked up a man and woman. The man is holding his hoodie over his head tightly, wearing a mask. Seems odd but more or less normal so I roll. In a few seconds I suspect he might be drunk, he is making strange sounds. I'm alarmed, ask what is wrong with him.

"He's in severe abdominal distress! Hurry!!" His is now groaning which becomes almost screaming. Looking in the mirror, I realize he is holding a gallon sized ZipLoc baggie containing vomit. 

Oh h.ell no.

"I am not comfortable with this trip. You need medical transportation."

"It's not contagious. Hurry!"

He says; "the mthr.fking ambulance costs $3,000. Just get me to the fking hospital. "

This ride is over. By now I have progressed around the block, there is a gas station and market, lots of people. I inform them that I am not comfortable with the ride, i am ending it here, they need to call 911 for an ambulance. 

He explodes. "Mthrfking racists mthrfkr! You just hate black people. You mthrfking racist!" This rant continued and got louder, and he wasn't moving. I stepped out and called 911. They realize what I'm doing, get out, he continues the rant and it now progresses into threats. I get in, drive across the street, tell dispatch the threat is over and no need to respond. then I call the Uber safety line and tell them what happened. 

About an hour later, I get an email.

"A rider recently claimed that you declined their trip based on the destination provided. We wanted to let you know about this report because refusing a trip based on destination goes against the  as well as local regulations in many areas, and could result in loss of access to the Driver app."

I responded with a detailed account of what happened and received an email in return basically said everything was OK.

So obviously the safety line does not share information with whatever department handles complaints.

Name: Bigz77
Story:
Picked up this pax in the private hanger at Ft. Lauderdale airport. This dude and his wife. These two had the whole rich thing going on. The jewelry, Louis Vuitton bags, lap dog with a diamond necklace. 

Loaded up all their bags for them and proceed to drive them to their hotel, have a great conversation on the way. They're asking me questions, I'm answering. Really good ride. Get them to their destination unload all their bags for them and thinking this should be an easy $20 tip for me. The husband whipps out wad of cash, at least $ 1000 if not more, all sorts of denominations, 20, 50s, and 100's.....hmmm, Mumbles something and says I'll just tip you on the app. Haha, I just laughed and said don't worry about it.

Name: Ian Richard Markham
Story:
If anyone can post the link to that thread and a link to the accompanying hour long sound clip of the ride that would be awesome. Please also feel free to summarize the thread to which I am referring or comment on SadUber’s character in general. 

Thank you,

Ian

Name: tothebeach2024
Story:
Mind you, I have a soft spot for disabled and special needs people. (My daughter is one). Got a ping and rolled up to pick up a lady that was crippled by cerebral palsy sitting on a bench in the hot sun. Helped her in the car and started the ride. Two blocks down the road to a lawyer's office to drop off a form! She said she didn't know how to add a stop so I showed her on the app and she said she needed to go home- 1 1/2 hours away in afternoon ATL traffic. She was very tired and I knew she wouldn't get a ride any time soon at that time of day, so I said add a good tip and I would do it. She agreed and off we went together, her talking non stop all the way. I even stopped and bought her a water. I helped her to her door and turned around for an hour dead leg back to ATL. 
Yep, no tip. I feel like I got played. I think this has been used before with other drivers...SO NO MATTER WHAT, END THE RIDE FIRST!
Sometimes it pays to refuse nicely if asked for a big favor. Honesty is a rare thing these days I fear. But I did my good deed for the day! May God bless her, she's got way more issues than tipping her drivers.

Name: Squirrel1138
Story: Today was my first day mashing the GO button. I was extremely nervous starting. After my first 3-4 trips I started getting the hang of it. I drive in a small city of 28k. I knew starting out that I wouldn't be making money like in the major cities. I do have to say that I am disappointed. 8 trips. $42. Over 5 hours. I did enjoy meeting the people. No bad ones. I will definitely have to give it another shot. Oh out of the 8 rides I got a 4.85 rating. Someone slipped me a 4 star. Not a bid deal but I wish they would have said something or at least left a review. I still have a lot to learn. Over all I still consider this a positive experience.

Name: Sdguy1
Story: Is uber x app is working now?

Name: MadTownUberD
Story:
Picked up a guy at a new apartment complex and took him about 10 minutes up the road this morning. 

A couple of minutes into the ride he appeared to be getting agitated, sighing etc. I did have to go backwards a little bit before heading towards the destination, because of the nature of the several lane road etc., but nothing too out of the ordinary. 

About halfway through the ride he asked if he could roll down the window. I said sure, no problem, and I cracked mine as well to avoid the reverb. I asked him if it was too hot and he said no (my A/C was set to an appropriate level).

I don't think he was concerned about COVID because he wasn't wearing a mask until right before he got into my car. I did have an almost full cup of very strong coffee, but I've never gotten a complaint about that and even regular compliments on the aroma.

I dropped him off at his destination and then it dawned on me: the egg salad sandwich I had purchased at a convenience store and placed on the passenger seat was giving off an aroma. If he had smelled it through the coffee aroma, he probably thought I was a gassy driver. I moved the sandwich to the hatchback before picking up my next pax.

Waiting for a bad rating or even a complaint, but I hope to avoid it. He was a 4.98, like me, so hopefully he gives me the benefit of the doubt.

Next time I think I will skip the egg salad sandwich.

I drove to it today three min 4 dollar rides . I want home . 112 dollars just under two hours .
