Name: Juggalo9er
Story:
I've been doing lots and lots of shuffling on Lyft... mostly showing up in a car not account.... generally I just collect cancel fee and move on... today was different....
Showed up at small apartment complex, pax texts and asks where I'm at......I, being the fine upstanding driver that I am reply with.... I'm right outside.... the pax scoured the parking lot looking for me and he found me, just as I was collecting my cancel fee

Moral of the story is, be patient, the cancel fees will come

Name: Young Kim
Story:
Had a pickup in downtown Chicago by the Hotel Intercontinental going to Scores Bar (a strip club), 30 minutes westbound. The pax asked if he could play DMX through my bluetooth. DMX is somewhat before the rappers I love like Wiz Khalifa, Travis Scott, The Weeknd, and Cardi B....but... when we listened to it, I was happily surprised by his gritty style, very "real" lyrics. The next ride from Scores brought me to the west side of Chicago and then the south side.

So I listened to him all night, and as I mentioned, once you get to the west or south side of Chicago, you don't often leave the area. This is because many drivers will avoid the area or log off once they drop off there. Therefore, if you get to the area and leave on the app, you will stay there all night. Many pax who came in were so excited and happy that an Asian would enjoy hip hop/ rap/ R&B, and congratulated me on my musical tastes.

I spoke to pax all night regarding DMX, his turbulent life, and his very depressing death. One young lady pax I spoke to said that DMX reminded her of her family a great deal... a very high functioning drug user. She talked about how her father uses PCP casually and does a good job to help the community and other people. She said that drug users should not be stereotyped as criminals. The young lady emphasized that once you demonize drugs and make it illegal, it glamorizes it and makes rebellious young people get into it more and more.

Pax talked about how music unifies and brings the world together, and DMX the rapper made incredible music. One pax kept using the word, GOAT, as an acronym to describe DMX (G=Greatest, O=Of, A=All, T=Time). It was amazing to see the impact that the death of a legendary rapper had on a community like Chicago. After my shift, I watched some of DMX's acting jobs with Jet Li... like in Cradle2Grave and Romeo Must Die. He was a very talented person!

Name: Seamus
Story:
Like many, I started Ubering and was as naive as could be. Uber just became legal in NY (outside NYC) in July of 2017 and because it was brand new both pax and drivers were trying to figure it all out.

Shortly after starting to Uber I started lurking in the UP forum for awhile before joining. It was somewhat of a different forum back then, more like a band of pirates giving tips on how to make more money and strategizing to beat Uber. Back then, Uber's AI was no where near as good as it is today and a driver had a much easier time manipulating the "system" to maximize revenue. Now forget it, Uber's AI is too good to beat except in rare circumstances.

I started reading in UP about longhauling, Shirlington Shuffling (deliberately not intending to give a ride) and creating surges. (Yes, believe it or not you used to be able to create surges)! I thought I would never do any of that in a million years. After dealing with Uber and pax BS, boy did that change! In the interest of space I'll just choose one (although I've done them all)



I thought it was terrible that a driver would deliberately boost up a fare, then I met "Karen". I took "Karen" on a 1.5x surge to JFK Airport in NYC from the northern suburbs. At a 1.5x surge with higher rates that was a very decent fare. Karen immediately became one of the most annoying pax I ever gave a ride to. She was a visitor to NY from Chicago and immediately started pounding and pounding what a terrible place NY was. Next, she found out that I was born in Scotland and spent the next 15 minutes telling me how bad Scotland was and that it was one of the "worse places on the face of the earth". She was crass, obnoxious, and extremely rude! The final straw was her telling me how "blatantly stupid" most Uber drivers were. That was it. OK Karen, we are going to JFK by way of Long Island!!! :roflmao:. If you look at my route it looked like a very pregnant line. FU Karen!

Do you remember your first deliberate shuffle, longhaul, throwing a pax out, etc .etc.? Something you thought you'd never do?

Name: momowns11
Story: Anyone having issues with the Uber eats app not letting you accept deliveries or log off?

Name: MyJessicaLS430
Story:
Not only recently did I realize that it was stupid of me to be "faithful" with Uber when I first started doing side gigs. Honestly I have never seen numbers like these back in the days when I was transporting human cargoes around. Do you set a weekly target? For me, it is $200 to pay for car insurance and phone bills. Sometimes, the numbers are so unreal that if I am able to make, say $500 by working a little harder, that would worth a month of car payment. Is this why there are so many brand new cars and even nicer luxury cars with Uber stickers?







While these numbers may appear as a child's play to some here on the forum, personally I do feel satisfied with the extra $ every week. The best part is that I drive a car that even carmax wouldn't take it🤣 such that depreciation is removed from the equation. It is such an amazing experience to be paid without having strangers in my car!

Name: Ummm5487
Story:
After driving for uber lyft postmate and door dash nearly everyday for the last 6 years last week at about 30k trip i was completely burnt out....it had got to the point my driving foot was always inflamed and being in the sitting position so much was giving me painful stomach problems...I realized i am a true workaholic...day 2 of my vacation i literally felt like I was going through withdrawal....I realized I had been letting life pass me by and running from things i didnt wont to deal with...after day 4 i was able to finish a few things that had been left undone and then i drove out of town and hung with my aging parents for a few days and had great get together with my siblings...
Today i got my ubermobile service and ready to hit the road with new brakes coolant fan.. rotors and spark plugs...come tomorrow ill be chasing uber 60 ride bonus challenge and be back in the rat race....but my stomach...foot and ride all feel brand new...i guess sometimes a vacation is all we need!!

Name: tohunt4me
Story: BEWARE !

Name: Young Kim
Story:
This pax made me feel very sorry for what he is going through. This ride was in the suburbs, to Bartett, IL from the north side of Chicago. My pax said his life was going very well, and he had a good job. No problems. Then his girlfriend made him very upset and treated him like trash. He started taking care of her totally and completely... emotionally and financially. He was so devastated, that he decided the best way to get back at her was to send her pictures of him shooting up heroin. He thought that doing so would make her feel terrible, and he would get even and in a way revenge.

Unfortunately, it resulted with him getting addicted to heroin and getting arrested for drug possession. He is undergoing treatment now. We had one stop on the ride, and I am very much of the impression that he was picking up drugs (likely heroin). The pax is not sure how much guilt he caused his girlfriend (now ex-girlfriend), because they stopped talking... I'm thinking those videos was not a wise move on his part. (I often disable my dashcam because pax will not talk if they know they are on camera. Therefore, I just record the audio on my phone, and make sure to keep my pax anonymous).

Here is the audio/video. He cried a lot after the video clip cut off. He could not believe that his girlfriend would take him for granted after he treated her like a princess.

Name: Cvillegordo
Story:
Drove to pickup Sharon. Waited four minutes. Sharon opens her front door and comes out. And keeps coming out....good lord she's enormous! Gotta be a 350 pounder. No problem, no judging. Sharon walks s-l-o-w-l-y to my car. Sharon stops at the door and rummages in her equally enormous purse, pulls out a spray cylinder of something. For a moment I honestly thought she was going to spray my car before getting in, but she proceeds to spray HERSELF! ALL AROUND, TOP TO BOTTOM, FRONT AND BACK! She even LIFTED HER LEG and got a little down there. No way, this is not happening! Holy crap, there's a FOG surrounding her now as she opens the door. I am instantly hit with a thick, cloying odor that smells something like b.o., fast food, weed, and cheap perfume. Trying not to gag, I brace as my car settles lower on the right side.

"Hi Sharon, I'm Walter."

"It's ShAYron."

"Oh. Ok." 

Off we go. ShAYron doesn't say another word. Thank the lord for short trips. Three minutes later, she rolls out and my car creaks back up to normal. Waiting to pull out into traffic, I watch, horrified, as she pulls out the body spray and hoses herself down again before knocking at the door of a townhouse. 

All around, top to bottom, front and back. Lift the leg.

Bye bye ShAYron.

Name: Rideshare Dude
Story: I dropped off a woman in her upper 50’s who is blind and raising two teenage daughters. On of those daughters has down syndrome.

Name: Justkeepswimming
Story: You’ve got 8 minutes!

Name: rkozy
Story:
The rideshare companies are definitely making good on their promise to recruit more ants. I hadn't seen a "Come Drive For Us" advertisement in a long time, but today I have seen several. One was for Uber. It featured a late 50s-looking woman who claimed to have MS. She couldn't work a normal job because of her medical condition, but Uber was kind enough to let her earn money on her own schedule.

Yeah. That sounds safe. Let's recruit people who have impaired motor skills to drive around gang-bangers and other fellow cripples.

Name: Young Kim
Story:
Picked up a young lady pax south of downtown Chicago around 1:30 am, and heard her talking to a guy in a hushed voice on the phone, "So you got what I need?, because I got the money..." She talked price on the phone and then hung up. We then started talking, and she said she was going deeper into the south side of Chicago to "complete a deal". She clutched her large purse and counted cash. I thought for sure it was something else, but I found out that she had human hair wigs in her purse.

She said this when I asked her how she is managing the pandemic with all the uncertainty in employment for everyone (This is one of my standard pax questions). She said, like many young pax, that she was self-employed, and bought and sold hair weaves and wigs. She explained that all her products come straight from Asia. She said, "It comes from your countries, China, Korea, and India." 

She said that the best hair and prices come from the East. She buys them from a secret source and then resells them. This is why she feels the need to hide them from law enforcement. "Human hair" wigs are not by themselves illegal, but she felt that if law enforcement somehow discovered the source, she could get into trouble (sort of like having cartons of cigarettes which escaped duty/ U.S. Customs/ tax)

When I asked her if I could see one, she looked behind us and around first, said, "Well, I don't see any police, so here is one". She showed me a few, and some were weaves and some were wigs (which one was dyed blond and brown). They looked very nice and high quality to me. The pax described her business, which was booming.

She said that there are smugglers of vast amounts of human hair which are often obtained illegally. She said that in some Asian countries, ladies have their long hair cropped off against their will, sometimes in cases of religious sacrifice (like when a "holy" leader will tell the lady that to show her love and devotion to a god, then she must demonstrate a sacrifice...like her long hair. (Which the religious leader will then sell). 

I didn't really know this illegal, but I guess the young lady knew that she cannot be in possession of large quantities of it. This puzzled me, because I know many wigs are made with real human hair, and I had no idea this would be illegal. She really acted like she had bags of illicit substances in her purse, which was my first guess. I am guessing that while a person can have maybe one of two wigs for personal use, if someone has many many such hair pieces, then it may not be permitted if it was determined that such products were smuggled into the U.S.? 

I suppose I found this pax ride interesting, because she told me that up to 90% of young ladies on the south and west sides of Chicago have wigs and hair extensions! I thought that young ladies just straighten their hair and then carefully take hours to "weave" them or braid them by hand. But my pax explained that almost always you are looking at a wig, not their natural hair. 

Then she surprised me by pulling up her own beautiful weave to reveal... a nearly bald shaved head! She said her ethnicity's hair "frizzes" so easily, especially in moisture, so it is far easier to have very very short hair and then just put on a wig / weave. The pax explained that she makes a very good living buying, creating, styling, human hair from the Asian countries, and there is a massive never ending market at least here in Chicago.

Name: Young Kim
Story:
Driving through this pandemic this past year I've had multiple customers complain that they could not get a Lyft ride. Since 1 year ago, as month after month passed, pax would often tell me that they tried to get a Lyft first because it was cheaper but the wait times got longer and longer.

Some of them were hardcore Lyft loyalists, but they have been telling me that around the new year it got really bad with wait times being over 45 minutes at least in Chicago. But recently they said they could not even get one at all! It would say "Lyfts are unavailable in your area." Or something like that..

A couple of customers last night told me that they are worried because they think that once Uber finishes off Lyft they're going to jack up the fares even more because then Uber will be a complete total monopoly and they can set the prices wherever they want. Many Uber ants have both apps up. 

Have you seen any dramatic changes in your experience as a driver if you have the Lyft app up?

Name: Cvillegordo
Story:
As if I needed a reason to make this a personal practice, another 3rd party ride disaster happened last night. 

Just before pickup, text from pax; "you will be picking up Anton, a friend of mine. He is going to the hospital, his sister just died."

Ok.

Anton (I assumed) was a disheveled black male of indeterminate age, as I pulled up to the house he was attempting to park a bicycle on it's kickstand. Ok. I waited until he finally gave up and leaned the bike against the house. 

"UBER?"

Yeah. Hop in.

Anton approaches with no mask and a bag of chips. 

You need a mask, and no eating in the car. 

"No problem."

Puts on mask, rolls chips up into a ball and gets in. Off we go. 

"We need to stop at a church. I'm from Charlottesville, I'll show you where to go."

Realizing that he didn't order the ride, asking him to put in a stop is pointless, so I ask which church. It's on the way, no biggie. Then he starts giving me directions, loudly, leaning forward towards the front, mask drooping below his chin. I realize he is very intoxicated. The directions turn into excited shouts; "TURN HERE! NO, THERE! LISTEN TO ME!"

We stop at the church. I turn and say; "you will not shout at me, and you will wear your mask if you want a ride." He gets out, leaves the door open and goes to the church door where there are several packages. All the while shouting obscenities at someone on his phone. This all happened in the space of a minute or less. I look in the back seat, chips and crumbs everywhere. F.uck this. I jump out, close the door, toss his chips on the street. End trip, drive away. I hear him bellowing curses for two blocks. One star, call support to document. 

I'm fine with third party rides. Uber needs to step up and strongly warn customers that they are responsible for anyone they place in an Uber. Or, simply not allow it at all.

Name: Sal29
Story: You'd think they'd behave after that Pakistani Uber Eats driver was just murdered by another uneducated loser like her.

Story:

I believe it's a dollar surge

Name: Ummm5487
Story: Despite the bad things people on this site like to call me, one thing they cant call me is lazy....Ive rip and ran doing uber non stop for the last 4 years even during a pandemic ..i rarely even take a day off....well ive decided now is time..its like the thought of doing even one more trip anytime soon is unbearable...ive saved enough money to retire...so maybe i will...time to live a life that dont involve sitting in a car 20hrs a day...maybe ill take a week or a month or maybe forever off!!!

Name: FLKeys
Story:
Standard every week day morning routine. Hit go to log on and answer the questions and take a selfie. After done set destination to work 14 miles away hoping to score a ride along the way and then hit the go online button.

Got up this morning and as I was almost ready to walk out the door for my day job I turned on Uber and hit the GO button to get the mask verification to pop up. No mask check instantly went online and immediately got a ping, unfortunately it was a vey long trip in the wrong direction. I decline it and go offline so I can set a destination like I do every morning. Set my destination and get kicked out to do the mask check verification.

Guess Uber was desperate to get this ride filed and tried to force it on me. Pretty sure someone missed their flight this morning.

Name: Guido-TheKillerPimp
Story: I learned the hard way not to eat tacos while driving 😭. How about you? What particular munchies got their revenge on you while navigating traffic?

Name: Young Kim
Story:
I drove up to a strip club in Stone Park, IL called "The Gold Room" (all purple lights outside), and picked up two guys and drove them into downtown Chicago this past Saturday night around 3:00 am. They came in mildly drunk but were incredibly happy. I remarked to them that I was surprised the strip clubs were open again because I had heard they had closed due to covid. The guy behind me told me, "No man, they reopened. I was so excited that I slapped each of the girls in the as# tonight thanking each of them for getting back to work."

On the way to downtown, one of the guys became very chatty and started talking a LOT about aliens and how he feels that they either created this world as a 3-D simulation and we are all living in a video game...or they are behind the scenes controlling it completely by assuming key behind the scenes roles. He went so far as to suggest that there are large underground military bases where the world leaders are collaborating with some alien races who wish to study humans. 

I could tell that he had studied a lot into this area, and he mentioned a lot of details about stories he read about famous UFO/alien sightings. Once in a while, his friend would chime in, and say that aliens must exist as there are endless worlds and universes out there. He then discussed how we are all sort of living in a human "ant farm" like environment where everything is controlled, and all variables altered to see how humans would react.

When he asked me my opinion on all this, I replied I can agree that there very well could be aliens, but until they show up and affect my life directly I am not interested. I told them that it is cool to ponder, but since I cannot prove or disprove their existence right now, it is not practical for me to think about it. After, he asked me if I had seen any. I told him no. He said he did see some before looking at the night sky with a telescope, and he saw some when he experimented with DMT, a powerful psychedelic drug. 

The ride ended though in sort of a funny way. About 2 minutes from our destination, the more quiet guy sitting on my passenger side rear suddenly ask me to drive faster because he had to go to the bathroom ASAP. I told him that I cannot risk getting a ticket, but if it is an emergency, I can pull over. He said fine and then he would be OK. Then, with about 30 seconds left, he screamed at me, "Pull over, pull over now, right NOW!" 

So I stopped quickly, and he got out and then his friend who was talking about all the alien stuff went out and both relieved themselves for a long while by a building wall. After, they both got back in, and the guy on the right said, "Dude, that was such a relief, thanks a bunch, I am gonna tip you $30 on the app ok!" Anyways the ride ended, and I was left entertained by those two.

Story: Surges were multipliers and there were 2 genders

Story:
I arrive at p/u location Pax is holding a very small baby. I roll down the window, door locked. I ask if they have a car seat for baby?
You guessed it. No car seat. WTF?

I tell them I Cannot legally transport a baby while being held in your arms.
Pax gets mad. Idiots! Too bad! Cancel and collect my few $'s

Name: ozzyoz7
Story: Long before driver even arrived. Crazy world huh? I'm supposed to tip a driver I cancelled on lol?

Name: Cvillegordo
Story:
We have a part of town called Belmont, an old Charlottesville neighborhood which has a cluster of nice restaurants in a very small half block area. If you're in the area and you like good Italian, check out Tavola. Last night I had a pickup at Tavola; "JaNAYzha" with a 4.3 rating. $5 promotion and $2 surge, short ride, why not? (Rhetorical question.) These restaurants are literally side by side, if you stop at one, you're there. Stopped at the PIN, texted the rider, waited 2 minutes and received a text; "you're at the wrong address." WTF. I look in my rear view and there she is 30' behind me, on the sidewalk, staring at me. Whatever. So I back up 30'. 4.3 JaNAYzha gets in, off we go. Beep! The rider has modified the trip. My 5 minute ride has magically changed to TWO minutes. Well, I still have the promotion and the surge. Beep! She just added a stop. F..k!!

Long story short; She was going to her house to "pick up something for work." I told her 3 minutes when she got out; she said "I'll be one minute." She was 3+, I was about to cancel, I have not done it already because I know lots of the other people that work in those restaurants, and at least she works. She hurries out, jumps in reeking of weed. No apologies, no tip. Good riddance. So I have given lots of people with similar names and bad ratings rides, and had good experiences, even got tipped. But I have given lots more the same and had BAD experiences and no tip. I am at the point where I am just going to make a blanket policy that I don't do rides under such "circumstances." Period. Just maintaining diamond until the 31st and then all bets are off.

Name: Young Kim
Story:
My first pax of this Sunday night was a guy I drove from Glenview, IL to downtown Chicago. He previously worked in the advertising business but was laid off due to covid. Now, he just started trying to make a living rehabbing houses and flipping them. On the long ride (35 minutes), we talked about a lot of things but mostly he complained about Uber and Lyft these days. He said that he and his friends were "die hard rideshare loyalists", but recently he started souring on both companies.

For example, he said that tonight (Easter Sunday), he could not get a Lyft or an Uber for over an hour until I accepted the ride. I drove 15 minutes to pick him up. Before I accepted the ride, he said that both Uber and Lyft told him some message like, "No drivers in your area, try again soon" or "Are you sure you wish to request, limited available cars"...something like that. He was so grateful that I finally picked him up, because he was just about to give up. He told me, "If you hadn't come, then I would have had to stay overnight with my ex-wife, so thank from the bottom of my heart for that!" 

He mentioned the ridiculous surge. Lately, he said the prices for both Uber and Lyft were equal or sometimes a lot more than what a taxi used to be. And.... there were no more quick pickup times (5 minutes or less) that he was used to for rideshare. Now, just like the taxi industry before, he would often wait up to an hour (as he was in the suburbs), for an Uber or Lyft to show...or "none available"...just like the taxis.

Therefore, he voiced active hope that the taxi industry would get themselves back together to shape and make a valiant comeback. We discussed how the Chicago medallions were a high of $385,000 back in 2013. Now, there is no bid... (no buyers). So he hoped that now that the prices are so incredibly low, there could be a chance for the "left for dead" taxicab companies to make a comeback...and wished eagerly for them to make an effort.

This got me thinking...

I was actually far happier for a multitude of reasons driving a taxi (part time I drove for Flash Cab and other companies) than driving rideshare for two very evil companies... I felt I had very more control over my destiny driving a cab. Plus, I paid zero attention to whether my car would depreciate, not have to worry that I could be "deactivated" for a nonsense complaint, etc. etc. etc. etc. etc.

What if?.....

Name: losiglow
Story:
Time for some comic relief. This thread is to post all the different kinds of pax we come across. 

The "5-some" pax - You show up and there's 5 pax and they want to jam 4 in the back seat. Usually followed by "Oh, I thought we ordered an XL!" Yeah, I bet you did. 

The "gotta take one last puff" pax - That guy who's smoking when you pull up. He takes one last puff, tosses the cigarette then gets in the car. 

The "interrogator" - It's pretty normal to be asked how long you've been doing Uber or if it's been busy today. But then there's the one who asks a hundred other questions. Do you like doing Uber? How do you like this car? So you drive Uber and Lyft? How does that work? Do you have another job? If so, tell me all about it! Are you from the area? Married? Kids? What's your craziest story? Ever had someone throw up in the car? On and on and on......

The "halitosis" - Self explanatory. Breath so bad that even if you try to breathe through your mouth you can still taste it. You look at the nav every 20 seconds, counting down the minutes. Once they get out you open all the windows and turn the fan on full blast. 

Add your own pax contribution :laugh:

It's not showing me the price. How much does it cost?" I asked where. "Trenton, New Jersey. I ride with you, my friends follow." Hahahaha! Sorry pal. That's just a tad too far and a tad too sketchy. "But how did you enter the trip without the state?" He showed me the address on his app, it was a street name that we also have here. So apparently the app was trying to calculate the trip but couldn't. Clearly it knew it was out of town, but not exactly where. I didn't realize this was even possible. The guy actually argued with me a little, I was patient but only to a point. Sheesh, f..k this, cancel. Theories on his intentions? Why follow the Uber if no bad intentions?

Name: Aw Jeez
Story:
In another thread, Benjamin M talks about how few drivers seem to be out there. Seems that way here in my town too (Pensacola, FL). A lot of people have suggested reasons - and maybe some of them are valid. Here's what I know...

I turn the Lyft app on first because it's less "fussy" than the stupid Uber app. ("Take a picture of yourself." Then, "Now take a picture with your mask on." And then, "Now give us a urine sample." It never ends!) Before I can even get Uber up and running, the Lyft app is sending me a trip. From that point on, it's go-go-go, stacked pings all day for as long as I want to drive. Yes, some of them are for far-away pickups and I decline as many of them as I can. Many days I don't even log-on to Uber.

I hear from a lot of passengers that they have loooong wait times, and sometimes they get a message that no cars are available. Damn! I had one passenger tell me how hard it was for him to get a driver to pick him up, as he was enthusiastically thanking me for coming to get him. I said, "Well, it *is* my job, dude." And he goes, "No, no. One driver told me that he doesn't do passengers anymore, he primarily just does food. Says there's more money in it." And I thought: Maybe that's why the passenger apps have been so busy these days - drivers are switching to food so they don't have to deal with...you know...people? May be... Maybe if I was in this for the money, I'd deliver food instead too.

People in general are becoming more and more dependent on ride-share to get around, even in the suburbs where there are typically fewer drivers. Lyft and Uber like to send you (meaning: me) all over hell for pickups. Given the option, I don't accept an Uber or Lyft ping that's over 12 minutes away. But Lyft is sneaky - they'll slide a new ride in when you've just begun the first one. I keep the volume on my phone down, so I don't always hear the, "New standard ride added to queue" announcement. 

I used to work six hours a day to make my "target" revenue. Now I do it in four or five. So I'm kind of with Benjamin M here. I kind of wish there were more drivers out in my town. It's F-ing busy here. And my fear is that the less-satisfied people become with ride-share, the more they'll gravitate back to taxis.

Name: Young Kim
Story:
In the past week I had at least three pax that told me that they are taking matters into their own hands and not going back to school (or not going to college). last night I picked up a pax at Dave & Buster's in Rosemont Illinois and he was upset that his college experience is being ruined because of covid. He is also irked because Northern Illinois University is not dramatically lowering his tuition costs. Therefore he is dropping out and he is going to try to learn how to program and design video games. He mentioned to me that he doesn't think school has anything like that he cannot learn on his own.

Another student I picked up yesterday was a 3rd-year student from a city college who also was feeling that he can make a lot more money doing things on his own than what he is learning at school. He felt that being an entrepreneur is far better than trying to work for a corporation in the future. He told me last night that he bought three used cars at auction last night and he will fix them up and resell them. He was super excited, and he talked all about how much profit he'd be making.

There was a third guy that just graduated from New Trier high School which is a highly regarded school where a lot of rich kids go to. That ride was about two nights ago and I remember he lived in Winnetka, Illinois which is a very affluent suburb. He was making a lot of money buying premium sneakers from online and in the north side and then he would drive to the south and the west side and sell them to inner city teenagers. He described that he could buy the sneakers himself for about $150 and turn around some of them to some of the teenagers the inner city for $400. He felt that he could make it his full time job after he finishes high school in a couple of months. He showed me his Instagram account where he showed off all of his shoes in his inventory.

I Ieel like at least this could be the start of a trend where a lot of young college age students are feeling that the very high cost of a college education is no longer worth it and doesn't add value. I feel like I've seen a trend at least myself where young college age passengers are telling me that they plan to take matters into their own hands.

Name: The Gift of Fish
Story:
There are a two points of view regarding post-your-boast earnings threads in which people post their earnings in various levels of detail; posting summaries only, providing full breakdowns of individual trips, or anything and everything in between. Some people say that posting earnings guides to one's own market is foolish. Others, judging by the number of them on here, think that they are great. My own opinion is that they certainly are foolish. However, they have also benefitted me, which seems contradictory. Here is my experience.

Late last year I was browsing this forum when I noticed a post-your-boast thread. "It's HOPPING in my town", posted the OP, who went on to describe in detail the goings-on in his local market. He had posted a screenshot of the driver app screen of his latest weekly earnings broken down by day, and also screenshots of several individual rides showing the spots that the rides originated, along with the day, date, time and value of each one.

"This is interesting", I thought. The area advertised by the earnings boaster is a smallish community around 40 miles outside a major metro area in California, which I knew vaguely. I have friends who live very close to it whom I hadn't seen in a while, plus things had been very slow in the Bay Area. I had also felt like taking a little vacation. So I decided to go and visit, and combine a vacation with a chance to make some good money. I had never driven rideshare there but my plan was simple. I would just go to the spots identified by the OP on the days and times advertised by him, turn on the driver app and wait.

And so it happened. One road trip later, I went to the first staging area, turned the app on and waited. Things turned out to be just as the OP had said. Demand was excellent and I soon bagged some great high-dollar rides, and a couple of very high dollar rides. Over the next week I was very pleased with the results. Interestingly, during this time, I picked up the same passenger three times from her house was a couple of miles from where I was staying, indicating that there were few drivers in the area. This, coupled with the nice surges and excellent ping quantity, was evidence of a very favourable demand:driver ratio in the area.

Now, back to the question posed above, regarding whether post-your-boast is a good idea, for both the poster and for me. Let's find the answer with simple cost:benefit analyses. If the benefits outweigh the costs then we'll say that it was a good result, and if benefits do not outweigh the costs, we'll say that it was not a good result.

For me, the costs of the exercise were gas to get to and from the poster's location, and the earnings I did not make in the Bay Area. The benefits were the earnings I made in his area, which exceeded the gas cost and my foregone home earnings by a country mile. So, for me, it was a good result.

For the OP, it's hard to estimate the costs of me working his area. When I accepted the pings there, I obviously denied those rides to all other drivers in the area. Was the driver one of those drivers? Was he working the area on the days and times I was? There's no way to tell. All we know is that it was possible. It's also possible that I was not the only driver attracted into his area by his advertising. Now, let's look at the other side of the analysis - the benefit side to him of advertising his area. This can be summed up as zero. In dollar terms, $0. Nada. As we said above, if the benefits outweigh the costs, then it is a positive result. However, with a benefit of zero, the benefits of advertising one's own area on a public forum can never, by defintion, outweigh the cost. The cost being, of course, the risk of losing business to competitors that one attracted into the area.

In summary, advertising one's area in post-your-boast threads is foolish, but the magnitude of the foolishness depends on the level of detail given. At the top of the tree, we have posting exact hotspots together with the days of the week and times to get good rides there. This will result in immediate competition from other drivers turning up. Further down the list of self-scuppering is the posting of daily earnings totals and the general location of the earnings. While one does not divulge the exact locations and times of the opportunities, it is still persuasive in attracting drivers, both old and new, into one's area. With zero benefit for the poster boaster, it is hard to see how this is a good idea. As seen above, there is no benefit to it for the advertiser. However, for the driver looking for new opportunities and areas to drive in, or for existing drivers who have taken a break and are considering returning to rideshare in their town, these posts can be golden eggs.

Conclusion - keep posting them, please! Just don't do it in my area. :thumbup:

Name: Young Kim
Story:
This was a first for me... after about 15,000 rides with Uber: a passenger this past Saturday night around 3:30 a.m. who I picked up from the city and brought for a long ride westbound began talking about how he was a Sicario (hitman) for the Sinaloa cartel. The conversation went in this direction when we talked about what colleges we went to. And we started on the topic of colleges because he had mentioned that I seemed so articulate. I told him I went to the University of Chicago and he lit up with enthusiasm and we talked about economics. He just said matter of factly that after college he unfortunately went to jail for several years because he shot somebody right next to his heart.

I picked up 49 seconds of the conversation but I stopped it after he began to go into great detail and told me his name and the person that he had shot. Obviously I stopped the video at that point. Here is the 49-second clip below which protects his anonymity:


after he told me that he had shot somebody and gone to jail and told me to look up his name on Google. I did so quickly at the next traffic light and indeed it was my passenger and I saw his mugshot. He then told me about how he had been to a couple of state prisons and told me about the life inside prison. Somehow he got out after several years.

He befriended some people with the cartel while inside prison when he was in jail. After leaving jail, he said he started to work for them. When I asked him why he did that because I told him it was so dangerous he said that the money is so good. Also he told me that the women are so plentiful that he has no problem finding beautiful young women all the time. He showed me on his phone at a couple of lights where we were stopped him posing with many beautiful women and him describing that he had been with all of them.

I think he could sense that I didn't quite believe his story (at first) and the reason that I was a little skeptical was honestly I thought to myself that if someone is actively killing somebody why would they tell some total random stranger?

Then he said, "I could sense that you doubt me so let me show you...". "look!". And then when I turned around he produced what he said was a loaded handgun. I did get scared at first but then I calmed down and then just asked him to put it away. He kept on asking me if I was wearing a wire. He also kept asking me if I wanted to take a bump of cocaine in the car. Naturally I said no to both. I told him that I would never use drugs under any circumstance and especially never while I was driving Uber.

I thought if I should try to get help while I was in the ride I figured it would not be a good idea to antagonize somebody in the situation that I was in. I quickly looked at the name on my app and it was not the name of my passenger. So I thought to myself if something were to happen then there wouldn't be any way to necessarily track him.

So I just stayed calm and listened to him tell stories of people that he's killed. They were both targets in Mexico and the US. He said he particularly asks for pedophiles and women beaters. Tell me about the fees that he collects and they're usually between three and $5,000 in the US. The most he got was $25,000. He described that there was a code of course of no women no children... however there were some unusual circumstances where things like that were allowed.

then he went into some graphic detail and asked me if I ever saw somebody's head getting cut off. I remember him also asking me if I ever saw several ks of cocaine live right in front of me. Then he told me about the time that he saw somebody get drawn and quartered by five different cars. Like they would tie each limb and the head to five different cars and then drive in different directions. It went into more graphic detail about people being boiled alive and many other things I won't go into.

it almost seemed like he was telling me his autobiography because he told me about names locations places he's done hits...I was extremely utterly surprised that he would go into such detail with somebody he did not know.

Anyway the ride ended and like I said I stayed very very calm and collected and I didn't report it to Uber or anything else. In fact he told me that the name on the account was just someone untraceable so I wouldn't even need to bother. Besides he told me that I could tell someone his story but I couldn't use any personal details... and I did not here. He did very calmly tell me it would be a shame that someone so cool and smart like me would suddenly disappear.

I wanted to share the story because it was highly unusual and it was probably the very first time while driving a passenger that I felt a little tingle of fear. I did not embellish or exaggerate even a single detail of the story here.

Yet another adventure in Chicago on a late Saturday night...

if I suddenly stop posting on this forum without any warning you will all know what happened to me ...and besides I would be on the news anyway... Be well everyone!

Name: #1husler
Story:
So I'm gonna pull a "Young Kim" (at the risk of owing him royalties) and talk about a random act of kindness that yours truly shared with a pax.

So this week I picked up a pax who just clocked off a 12 hour shift and was going to his girlfriend's place....he asked me if I "wouldn't mind" going to the drive thru liquor store so he could bring over a 6-pack. 

These are the kinds of overtures I ALWAYS turn down (because it opens up a portal of time wastage and drama)...I was about to say "no sorry" but then glanced through my mirror at this guy who had gotten off his shift and just wanted to relax with his woman and beer, and I thought...I can do it just this one. 

We stop at the drive thru liquor store, he orders his 6-pack but "can't find his ID" and the cashier won't make an exception for him... he's really frustrated and tells me "hey, lets just get outta here", so I put the car in drive, but then again look at through the mirror at him, pause, put the car in park, call the cashier back and say "I'm ordering what he just ordered".

The pax passed a $20 up to the front seat, I pay and try give him the 6-pack and this change, and says "no mann, just keep it".

I dropped the pax off...drove off and realized I had unwittingly performed a random act of kindness toward a pax.

Name: Young Kim
Story:
My last pax of the night I found particularly interesting because her story was unique. She had found a sugar daddy. I picked her up around the Edison Park Illinois area and brought her to the DoubleTree hotel in downtown Chicago. We got to talking and I asked her how the pandemic has affected her.

She told me that it was pretty rough when the pandemic started because she had been working at McCormick place as one of those young women who are hired to promote displays. it's a business convention center and frequently they hire young ladies to cater to the businessmen who are coming in and show off whatever company they're representing.

During one of the conventions an older gentleman had befriended her and they exchanged phone numbers somehow. After some communication they didn't talk for a little while. Once the pandemic struck, she lost all of her gigs at the convention center,... some of which paid her upwards of $38 per hour to basically stand there.

Is she contacted the older gentleman and they made an agreement. He would come into town and pay her visit in a hotel... and they would I guess be companions for the short time he was in Chicago. She actually has a young son that she must take care of so meeting him and him agreeing to be her supporter was quite fortunate for her.

I asked gently her if she enjoyed his company and the entire arrangement, and she seemed just okay with it. Like she didn't say that she really loved him or that she hated him or anything like that. For her it was just kind of a business arrangement to help her support herself and her young son. Of course she didn't tell me the amount, and obviously I didn't ask but she said that he sends her money every month

I thought this was interesting because during this pandemic people must cope in all sorts of different ways. She was actually the first person I met who actually had a real sugar daddy. she did tell me that he was happily married with children., But that did not bother her because of course that's not what she wanted because he was probably around 50 years old. I couldn't be sure but he actually came out to greet her cuz he was so excited, so I got to briefly see him.

Name: MyJessicaLS430
Story:
While I have no idea how the glorious days were like when these RS companies first emerged, there is no question that the rates are paltry these days. With the combination of multiple rate cuts, deteriorating passengers and the pandemic, I have decided to quit once and for all.

Recently I have been obsessed with deliveries, most of which are grocery shopping. At first it sounds ridiculous to me to be paid Uber rate to not only transport cargoes but also include the shopping component. Contrary to my expectation, this is very addicting. Don't be mistaken, I am not saying grocery shopping gigs are better than Ubering in any part. Although the base pay is about $6, consider the amount of time needed to complete one delivery, this is certainly not worth the effort without any incentives. What I mean by "incentives" are in nature, not the useless badges and ratings.

First, I love the upfront information about expected pay, time to completion and pick-up and drop-off locations, all of which we are supposed to be entitled to, not to be provided only if certain outrageous criteria are met. Here comes the best part, the monetary incentives. Depending on the local markets and time, the estimated payout (with bonus included) can be far more attractive than doing rides, not to mention you will have full control of where to end up after a delivery. Needless to say, how much we take home is also highly dependent on the willingness of customers to tip. However, if you are the type that withdraw every penny after each delivery, this may not work for you because there is a $500 cap. Personally I have no problem for these companies to keep the money for a year if there is a minimum of 1% interest rate 😂.




Finally, I am also astonished by the real time support. For instance, a transaction will be denied by default when customers request additional items after we accept an order. It only takes a minute or two for the support to override the payment authorization. They are also very helpful to assign a return for unsuccessful deliveries. Since not every store accepts return because of the pandemic, basically I have free food plus the $5 to drive back to the store. The only time that happened to me also include some adult products. Um may be I should consider selling them.

Name: Benjamin M
Story:
My last pax was number 3,000 on Uber, some two months or so ago. Eats since then, I grew tired of the ridiculous distance to pick up, no surge, and horrible pax ratings. 

Today, no decent pings downtown for delivery, so I decided flip on X. And, for the first time since the pandemic, I was getting stacked pings with surges, airport trips, and people hitting the town. Just like old times. 

While I find Eats far less stressful, it's nice to see my city coming alive again. 

How are the rest of you doing? Are you seeing a return to the typical pax from prior to this mess?

Name: layla8080
Story:
I drove Uber for 4.5 years with 8900 trip with high rating.
My account been suspended for almost 5 weeks, base on 100% wrong report on my DMV, Uber relies on Cheker report and all that department does run the same report.
My action to be fix the issue to be able to make appointment with DMV, almost impossible, and managed to get appointment 40 miles away in 45 days.
I have submitted all supporting documents and request the report to be corrected to both Court (still closed) and DMV as well.
Briefly> almost 6 months ago I hit in parking lot, no damage to my car at almost zero speed.
Receive letter from DMV to file the accident report, indicated at the time of accident I did not had insurance coverage. I had official letter from my personal insurance indicated at the time of accident no fault , no damage and no gapes in coverage for even 11 months period. as well since my Uber app was on, I spoke to all state indicated fr my part no action needed, and of course fax the accident report.
on 11.29 3.30 am, on the way to pick up rider, stopped by officer going faster than limit, but I was told my license suspended , 5 days prior to that date, of courseI did not know and the reason not reporting accident report. within 8 hours I was able to contact DMV by phone and they located the fax and removed the suspension, right away I contacted police department and spoke to officer to gave back my license, he refused and told me he will send it to DMV, waited couple weeks, 20 miles away to get my replacement. I send a letter to court, regarding the ticket ($460 charge for suspension), my mistake, the clerk told me, the court closed and judge willing to reduce the charge, I thought ok, they had to remove suspension charge, she did not indicated they changed the suspension to driving without driver license, that, s the code Uber wants to be corrected, as the result I had to let my car go, financed just for driving Uber. and Cheker wont accept any documents to support my case. to me Uber as well does not care about responsible drivers and at least look at the facts, not report that may takes months to be resolved during Covid.

Name: Young Kim
Story:
I dropped off a passenger to Gary Indiana. The ride only took about 31 minutes from the south side of Chicago! He and his sister actually work in Chicago but they live in Gary Indiana, because he said that it was so much safer than living in the south side of Chicago where there is much more crime. We entered his suburb and I remember asking him "how much do houses cost around here?"

I was stunned at his answer. He told me his house cost him only about $15,000 before closing costs last year. He said there was a slightly renovated one that was a few houses down that was $40,000. I was kind of in disbelief because his subdivision was not dilapidated or run down at all.

granted this was the night so I couldn't get a good look but there did not seem to be any trash or any boarded-up houses or lawns that seemed not well-maintained. It just looked like any other subdivision that you might find in Chicagoland. When I finished the ride I remember I went on redfin and verified that houses in his subdivision really were only about 15 to $40,000 in that area!

I just was so stunned that houses could be so cheap. this is before the pandemic but I remember I went on craigslist and I saw a parking space in river north Chicago which is in downtown Chicago selling for $55,000! And that was just a parking space! To be able to purchase a home for between 15 to $20,000 it just seems so incredible.

Indeed a 30-40-minute drive to downtown Chicago is not very close but if you can get a house for next to nothing,...well I can imagine why some people would choose to live out there.

Name: FLKeys
Story:
Two bottles in one day. Last night I had two separate PAX leave unopened bottles of wine in my car. One has not replied to the left item message from Uber so far. I know they were flying out this morning so I am guessing they won't be asking for that bottle back.

No idea who left the other bottle as it was neatly tucked away in the seat pocket and one of my other PAX pointed it out.

This will make the 4th and 5th bottles of wine left in my car over the years. I have not checked the value of them yet, they don't look like anything fancy. A couple of the other bottles left are quite expensive. I don't drink, so these bottles sit properly stored in a little wine rack that I have had for many years that always sat empty.

Name: Seeu
Story:
My first ride was March two years ago. My wife tried out Uber then hooked me up with a 50 rides/$750 bonus so why not, at least 50. Pick up is some dive with an Irish name, maybe a dilapidated shamrock painted somewhere, lots of fluorescent beer ads. 

An actual drunken leprechaunish Irishman hops in front -- a roofer. Ten minute drive to Upper Darby. Hes lit and loutish like the town drunk in early Irish novel, nearly incomprehensible. 

But two minutes in the ride he musters enough Anglish to ask if I can stop first at his dealers' place. Nah, man, nah, can't do it, the app will know, I lied. I drop him off and he tells me theres no cash brother I'll get you on the app (kiss of death). He then grabs me with his Krakken roofer destroyed hands and proceeds to pull me toward him (I'm 6'5 250) and I'm --- well --- what are you gonna do this guy says goodbye by touching foreheads; forcefully. Then he left; gawddamn weird Irish foreigner.

Name: MissAnne
Story: So much RED !!! This is more surge than I have seen in a year!!

Name: Fusion_LUser
Story:
I had a good Friday/Saturday evening last weekend and I was at home catching up on a book with the TV on when I got a ping for a long ride! My longest ride by far at 175+ miles. Before this request my longest ride was about 86 miles. I had been sitting at 3.5x starting around 3PM and did take a quick ride around 4PM for $38 but then Uber signed me out and forced me to take a selfie which I did. When I signed back in I forgot to change my fare multiplier so if I was at 3.5x who knows if I would have even got the 175+ mile ride... There were other ants available so I was surprised it came in at 2.1x. I guess the other ants didn't want the ride...

Anyway I saw the amount and did a quick screen shot then accepted the ride, thinking it was a high surge ride to Santa Barbara in the $300 range. It wouldn't be my first $300+ ride to Santa Barbara so I was OK with the blind accept. I then looked at the screen shot and saw it was to LA! Oh man, do I want to do this at 6PM on a Sunday???

So I go to The Boss who is prepping her lesson plan and for the next two minutes or so we talk about the ride...

I have a juicy $300 or more ride. Gotta go!
Where?
LA!
LA! Are you serious?
<mumbling> yes
You are going to LA at this time? You won't be back for hours!
It's gonna be like $50 an hour so why not?
CUZ IT'S LA!
Should I cancel?
It's up to you, that's a long ride. You are just watching TV so go, be safe!

After that nod of approval I did a quick bathroom break, grabbed a Rockstar and took off at 6:30PM. The pick up was near me in a newer part of town and a father/uncle/lover/pimp with his daughter/niece/lover/hooker was waiting for me. Just the lady got in my car and didn't speak one word of English. I confirmed the address with the guy and off we went. The lady fell asleep within 20 minutes and was slumped over in the back seat for about an hour and then just kept to herself in the backseat, it was like nobody was even there.

The ride was non-eventful until about 20 minutes from our destination. She took a speakerphone call in Chinese and then out the blue she just put her phone right up to my face! I could not see anything but the blue screen in my right eye! She said "talk" and the person on the phone was saying "Hello?"... I took the phone, said hello and the person just wanted to confirm the drop-off. I said that's the place and that was that.

I did miss a turn in LA, it was dark and there was a lot of traffic so I had to do a U-Turn at a light and a guy waiting for her at a Chinese restaurant when we arrived at 9:15PM. Both said thanks and off they went. Uber paid over $317 and they gave a $60 tip. Not bad for the first 3 hours!

I was getting ping after ping for local rides anywhere from $2 (outrageous... who the hell drives for $2???) up to $20 but I didn't know the locations and I didn't want to go out of my way so I turned on the trip filter and I was still getting a lot of pings! I did see one 2.0x for $25 to $29 from Union Station to Studio City (about 17 miles) and took that. I got another ride at 1.8x for $44 ($24 plus $20 cash tip) from the Warner Center in Woodland Hills up to Calabasas that was not much out of the way at all. I got sporadic pings for the last 150 miles home that I ignored.

I get home at 12:45AM... 6 hours and 15 minutes total for the 3 rides and one bathroom stop in Ventura... 345 miles and just a little over $450 for doing the entire trip. I used about a half tank of gas... I started with a little over 3/4 and ended with a little less than a 1/4.

Uber Ping and Stride time/mileage deduction screen shots.





Check out how Uber claims it only takes 128 minutes to drive 170+ miles! 🤣 🤣 🤣

Name: csullivan68
Story: I frequently pick up intoxicated female passengers who are very aggressive and inappropriate. They are constantly touching me and asking inappropriate questions about my sex Life. Why can females get away with this but men are demonized for it. It is an extremely unfair double standard.

Name: Young Kim
Story:
I had a pickup in Mount prospect Illinois with a pax named Margaret who was going to a bar in Schaumburg Illinois. Hers was a fascinating story about how covid changed her life and completely turned everything around.

She works currently for Comcast and is a technical support agent. She said that when the pandemic struck last year they offered everyone who worked a 25% bonus in their hourly salary. Then because of the pandemic she was promoted finally to being a manager.. with a big salary raise in addition to the 25% bump.

Then all the sudden she said she felt like she hit the jackpot because Comcast said that everyone could work remotely. She said that was such a relief because she said that initially her office was in Schaumburg then they moved her to oakbrook and then finally to Bolingbrook Illinois. Her commute times went from 12 minutes to 30 minutes to 1 hour when she finally got located to Bolingbrook Illinois. The commute was killing her because sometimes when there was traffic it would be an hour and a half back home..

she loved being able to just work from her pajamas because she doesn't even have to be seen since she's a technical support agent. Then recently she said that they introduced at Comcast a text support feature. that means she doesn't even have to be on the phone anymore with a headset! She said that was a godsend because she was sick and tired of having to continue to talk to customers who would ramble on and on. She didn't have to talk over them anymore. 

She said she could also listen to music which she said was a first while she was working. She would just blast music and then she'd be on video with friends just hanging out. Sometimes she would just go to friends homes and even restaurants and just do her work from there.

She also said that she had just recently bought a brand new car because her old one broke down. But because of the pandemic she said that she was able to sell her car to her friend who gave her a very good price. so now she no longer has a car payment or has to pay for any insurance and just takes Uber when she needs to go somewhere but she says it's not often.

She said with all the promotions in the bump up and pay and the incredibly relaxing work and being able to sell her car that her finances completely turned around. She told me that she's saving up so much money for extended vacations to Italy and France and all around the world. she said she could never save money before the pandemic. She just yesterday got her third stimulus bonus by direct deposit as well.

She admitted that she feels terrible about this because she's knows a lot of people have gotten sick and died and she feels guilty about admitting to anybody how she feels. but she admitted to me that she's had a hard life and after years and years of difficult times, the universe finally rewarded her personally with the pandemic... She said her life was now better than ever. Better than it's ever been in her entire life. I've had a lot of pandemic stories that were somewhat positive in the last year but this one blew all the others out of the water...

Name: BobDaScotty
Story:
I have posted of late negatively about my Philly core demographic.

Now, here is the flipside.

Rider, mid-thirties, very curious about my accent, we got chatting. 30 minutes later we are well into each other's life stories and were discussing daughter parenting tips. 

Poor guy had a deadbeat mom situation with the courts bending over backwards to ignore that if the sexes were reversed he would be doing jail time.

He got out the car at a wawa and we shook hands goodbye. 


Another rider, veteran, discussed the world with me and all it's problems, including his son stationed overseas. Great guy. Sadly had to turn down his invite for me and kids to a family potluck because uber policy. 

I have many other heavily tanned such riders that make doing the job almost ok.

I really wish we could go back to segregation but with decent people / @$$holes.

Name: ANT 7
Story:
Had to happen sooner or later, statistics being what they are.........3 years and almost 9,000 rides.

Stopped in the shitter lot at the airport to have lunch, because I just dropped a pax off for his flight. Dude parks beside me and walks over......checking out my vehicle body and then asking me for my documents. Of course my "tax receipts" were in order  so I talked to the guy for about 10 minutes before he left.

I asked him and he said he easily busts 1-2 drivers a day just by cruising into the waiting area at random. It's a big ticket too he said. Also, a lot of vehicles with evident body damage get their TNC licence pulled on the spot if they get caught. That is also as frequent according to him. He drives thru there 4-6 times a day according to a couple of the drivers I talked to after he left. My math tells me that about 3-400 Uber drivers are on the roads in our market over 24 hours at some point, so the number seems pretty low overall.

These dudes also told me that wait times are 2 - 2.5 hours for a ride right now. Why the **** do they sit there ? Max $ run to the end of our city is about $35 net to you if you are lucky enough to get one. Most are DT which pays $15.

Long Story short... I tossed a iPhone in the trash because I couldn't find a porta-potty...

I got a ping at a local sushi-bar to a local dive at 2.8x and the ride was about 8 minutes. Red flags did appear early but I ignored them because the ride requestor was pretty chill. As bad as she was the girlfriend appears at 5 minutes as I was about to cancel but the boyfriend was chill and said sorry about this... "It's her birthday..."

This is the most lily-white chick I have ever seen. Take every white chick from a John Hughes film and combined them all and you have the birthday girl. However *every* other word out of her mouth was "*****" and/or "****". In to the car she sits yelling "It's my birthday N***as! Lets party!"

We get out of the parking lot...

Where the **** are we going?
To the bar like you said you want to go...

I get to ****ing be obnoxious on my BIRTHHHHHHDDAYYYY!

Fusion....

Where is the ****ing gift I got? Oh here it is. Look at this Uber!

**** YOU N***A I WAS JUST BEING NICE. **** YOU *****" as she gets out and slams the passenger side rear door.

She immediately opened the door again and screamed "**** YOU *****" and slammed it again. I locked the doors quickly this time and drove off. I did see the boyfriend laughing so now I'm like **** that guy! I went to another parking lot to file a complaint with Uber when I get a call from Uber messing the little complaint I was writing. Then the Birthday Girl's iPhone in the back seat starting ringing!!!

I don't answer my cell but I answer her cell phone and the nicest way I could

Hellooooooo

I hang up.

Phone rings...

Hellllllllooooooooooo!

The birthday girl is still in the background yelling "if that ****ing Uber if he doesn't bring my phone back right now I'm ****ing calling the police and reporting it ****ing stolen."

Name: Young Kim
Story:
One of my riders last night was a pickup from downtown Chicago going to a Northwest suburb last night. His name was Augustus. Nice conversation to start. I talked about sports (Cubs and Blackhawks) and then the weather. (There was rain last night in Chicago)

Then he suddenly asked me a question from out of the blue... "What did you think about what happened during the elections?". (My interior caution light went off of immediately). So I proceeded with caution...

I told him "I'm not sure what happened but I know a lot of people thought there was some suspicious activity in the election".

(Augustus): thank goodness I found someone else who agrees with me and half the country.

(Me). well I really can't comment too much because I don't know enough about the matter but what I read on various news outlets was that there was really irregular voting activity.

(Augustus). I looked out myself personally in Wisconsin and saw that there were more votes for the senators in the state than for the president. Who would go to a voting booth and not vote for the president? Also how could biden have gotten more votes than Obama? Why was there reports of hours passing in certain voting booths with 100% of the votes going for Biden and none for Trump? There was massive massive voting mail in ballot fraud.

(Me) not sure. I can see why many people would consider that.

(Augustus). You know it's really hard being a Republican in Chicago right?

(Me). Yes indeed. if you wore a red maga hat in downtown Chicago I think people would start hitting you.

(Augustus)...(he went on and on and on about how the Democratic policies were just destroying the country. He brought up how he thinks Kamala Harris is certainly going to become president if not Nancy pelosi. He told me that if Biden cannot serve 2 years then Nancy pelosi automatically according to the law becomes the president. (I'm not sure myself). He talked about how President Biden when he reads a teleprompter once he read the closed captioning brackets that introduced the next event. He said Biden was completely utterly demented, who is a puppet who is hiding in the basement. He continued saying Trump will prevail again in 2024. A lot of lies he said were spoken about the Democrats about the lethality of the virus... It went on and on and on ..and on.

(Me). (I just kept silent, trying to keep my integrity by not totally agreeing with the stuff about Trump's absolute greatness, vaccine data, masks, etc. BUT at the same time not arguing with Augustus. I stayed pleasant calm and polite throughout the entire interaction and ride. And listened with intention.)

At the end of the ride I found a $22.23 tip on my app...

Name: The Gift of Fish
Story:
Uber recently lost its challenge in the UK courts to have its drivers classified as independent contractors. In a nutshell, the UK Supreme Court judged Uber's claims that it is merely a software platform that links pax and drivers to be nonsense, and that its drivers are indeed employees. Uber's reaction to making its UK drivers employees?



And:



So, in the UK, Dara and Co. accept that the UK ruling that its drivers are employees is a clearer path forward in giving its workers rights, and that it is willing to change its ways.

However, in California, the company sings along to a completely different tune. Voters decided in the Prop 22 election that Uber's drivers are not employees, but independent contractors. Uber's reaction?



And:



In California, Uber praises voters for deciding the polar opposite of the UK, and that decision to  class its drivers as employees is the best for the drivers.

Double-speak much? We, as drivers, have known for a long time that Uber has its bullshit generator running 24/7. However, up until now, the bullshit had largely been consistent. Now, Uber demonstrates that it will say whatever it thinks will benefit it the most, adapting the rhetoric at will to whatever situation it finds itself in, regardless of any contradictions with previously published positions.

Such duplicity would worry me greatly as an investor, particularly with reference to Dara's claims surrounding promised future profitability. However, with Uber's stock price still on an upward trend, none of this seems to worry the market. Go figure.

Sources:

Name: dtwguy
Story:
This evening I picked up a passenger in Detroit. They weren't at the pick up location. I figured out that they were around the corner and down the street. When I got there they immediately started calling me names after getting in the car. Soon, they began calling me "gay", "******ed", "ugly ass" and using the N word repeatedly. 

I asked them to stop swearing and to just confirm their drop off (since the pick up was incorrect) and name. They continued to call me names and swear, yelling at me. Eventually, I called Lyft's emergency ride number. The ADT rep was wonderful. After hearing a few seconds of this, including the threats to "F up my gay ****** ass" they recommended calling the police or immediately ending the ride. I explained that the passenger was four minutes away and there was no easy way to get them out of the car. They said they would stay with me out of a concern for my safety. 

They continued to yell similar racial and other hateful comments as I drove ("no one will ever suck your Dxxx you ugly gay ******"). I remained silent and got them to their destination. Fortunately they got out, while still threating to kill me. 

The ADT safety rep was wonderful. She was kind and recognized that I was in shock. She offered assistance and stayed with me until I could breathe again. 

Lyft? They sent me an email asking me to call them. When I did they said they were too busy and to send them an email. 

Oh, and while I was on the phone with ADT emergency support they assigned me a new pick up. I'm a 5 star drive so I pulled it together and drove there. The passenger didn't show up. After waiting ten minutes and calling and texting six times I cancelled. I received a message that "I needed to drive close" even though I was a foot from the front door". I'm still trying to get my cancellation fee. Fortunately I took a phot of me right under the address and at the front door! 

Meanwhile, there is a disturbed passenger out there willing to make multiple threats to kill a Lyft driver - and Lyft could care less. 

Be safe out there. 

#worstnightever

Story:

Name: The Gift of Fish
Story:
As I was completing a ride yesterday, just before getting out of the car, the pax said, "This is for you". She reached over and put something on the armrest between the two front seats. "Thank you very much", I said. I then thought to myself, "$10? $5?". Alas, no, it was a bible-basher propaganda pamphlet with a cartoon picture of Satan on it, horns 'n' all, with the words, "He's in disguise" or some other such nonsense. Not the disguise I've ever seen - I took one look and thought, "That's Satan". Epic tip fail.

This is actually worse than my previous worst tip record holder. I had picked up a couple from a restaurant, and at the end of the ride the female pax offered me her table scraps that she had brought out with her, classily presented in the form of a paper plate covered with aluminium foil.

What has been the worst tip a pax has tried to offer you?

Name: bone-aching-work
Story:
I had been driving Lyftrash around for a few hours when I got a close-by ping for a man I've previously given rides to. Each time he has tipped me $5 on top of a lengthy trip.

Then comes the dreaded re-routing message. Ugh. The new ride's pick-up is 4 minutes away, at a grocery store. Usually I'd just cancel, but this was close enough, and it's a 50/50 chance the pax will be an employee leaving work.

I roll up to the front entrance, hit Arrive, and check out the destination... less than 1 mile away. I look inside the lobby, there's a frail, old woman leaning on a grocery cart with all her bags.

Cancelled. See ya later.

She's probably still waiting there. The cheese has taken almost all the drivers off the road here. Lyft shows high demand across the city, but can't cough up any dough for drivers to share in the surge. I was averaging about 10-15 declines during rides when it was trying to stack distant pick-ups on me.

These Lyft executives absolutely will not budge on increasing minimum fare compensation or distant pick-up premiums, so the customer experience is awful.

Name: #1husler
Story:
So I rolled up to an apartment yesterday morning to PU....parked directly on the "pin", no pax yet in sight, so proceeded to do some reading... moments later to get a pax message, "I'm in front of you, don't you see me?!", I looked up and...sure enough, pax was standing (waiting) like 15 feet in front of me...apparently needing me to PU exactly parallel with her...I presumed she might have mobility issues, but as I dropped off she seemed to be walking ok on her violation.

At least this is better than the reason-challenged question I get from pax "Im right behind you, don't you see me?!", as if drivers have eyes in backs of their heads to see you standing behind their car. If its an residential neighborhood, I'll also get "didn't you see my house number?" [its night, I'll be one house off, but rather than walk that one house over...pax is standing at his/her house number with an expectant expression on his/her face... I don't mind backing up 20 feet so his/her royal highness's feet don't get tired with the walk...only that I wish FUber would include a red carpet with their "COVID supplies", so I could park, roll out the red carpet for his/her royal highness to enter their chariot (to go to "Le Dollar Generale").

Perhaps the worse is getting the "Im right behind you, don't you see me?!" in a super busy commercial district where yours truly would have to take a few mins to go around the block in order to line up the pax car exactly with the pax feet, about 15 feet behind where I am...this I don't do, but instead invite them to walk the 20 feet forward for the PU....if it appears they can't walk do to disability, then ok, but if not for that reason...then I cancel and save the red carpet for the next pax.

Name: touberornottouber
Story:
Sitting here during Daytona Bike Week. Got $20 for 5 rides so far. No surges at all today or yesterday. Last couple the guy tells me he is paying $27 for the ride. I'm getting $3.50.

Drop him off and it starts pouring down rain like a hurricane. They already gave me a queued ride at Starbucks (so probably a short ride with someone who doesn't want to walk in the rain). I cancel it and go to sign off. Before I can do that another pops up. repeat, then again and again. Eventually I am fast enough to sign off before they can pop another ride to me.

Yeah, I'm going to work in this weather for $4 a ride when you are charging the riders 500% surge. Go get 'em yourself Lyft. I'm staying home!

Name: Young Kim
Story:
My first riders last night were around 7:00 p.m. it was kind of a tiger mom in an upscale neighborhood in Illinois called park ridge. The mom was with her daughter who was in high school. Definitely had to be main south high school because that's the area we were in. it's definitely full of rich people and that's where Hillary Clinton went to high school.

The daughter was explaining to the mom that there was no hybrid options anymore but it was all in person or remote only for classes. I overheard the daughter explaining to the mom that she wanted to see her friends and be in person. 

The mom was then very anxious and said "well then I want you to double mask and wear a face shield". And then the daughter spoke back to the mother in a very polite way and said "Mom I will triple mask!". 

I'm serious I almost chuckled out loud when she said that she's going to triple mask. doing one mask already for me is annoying I can't imagine if I had to wear three of them and a face shield on top of that! 

The funniest thing is the mom looked at the daughter and just nodded slowly and was grateful that the daughter was so compliant and acting proper.

Name: mikes424
Story:
Not often do I see posts about happy riders but here is one. Picked up a girl (yes she was 18) who had Down's syndrome and drove her to her special education facility. My radio was playing Patsy Cline's "Walking to New Orleans." I hear a voice in the back seat singing along. The song was still playing as she got out and walked to the entrance. As she walked to the door she couldn't hear the song anymore. However it was still playing in her mind as she walked, no danced, to the door. 

Listening and watching her made my day.

Name: FLKeys
Story:
...as measured on Goggle Earth.

Last night I was driving down the highway at 50 MPH, 96 feet in front of me someone turns left in front of me. Luckily I had just checked my mirrors and knew the lane next to me was empty. I did not even have time to blow my horn. Slam on the brakes and swerve into the other lane just barely missing the passengers side of their car. 

96 feet sounds like a long way, when you are traveling 50 MPH it is around 1 second. Factor in 1/4 second reactionary time to realize someone pulled out in front of you and another 1/4 second reactionary time to do what your brains says to do it was way to close for me. I was inches away from hitting them.

Name: The Gift of Fish
Story:
This was a strange one. I got a ping to a Residence Inn for a late night 20 mile trip. I arrived at the pickup but there was no pax to pick up. Nothing unusual about that, but I then got a text from the pax, "Skip", asking me to call him. I don't usually phone or take calls from pax, but it was a reasonably good trip in the direction I wanted to go, so I hit the Call Passenger button in the Uber app. The phone rang out and nobody answered. Then "Skip" texted me that he wanted me to call him on a different number. I obviously refused. "Skip" then claimed that it was necessary for me to phone him in order "to confirm" and "to be safe", which makes no sense. Anyway, in the end I "skipped" the ride - ending this encounter with [cancel as no show / 4 bucks for me / thanks for playing / try again soon].

The last text that "Skip" was typing in the screenshot below was a rather desperate sounding "Call me!!!!". Clearly the scammer wanted to speak to me and/or to get my phone number, but I don't see why / what the scam angle would be. Maybe it's a new fishing technique to get drivers' numbers so that "support" can phone them later directly to pull the scam where they offer drivers a bonus in exchange for handing over their login details? The very American name of "Skip" combined with the very poor English makes me think foreign scammer.

Anyone know what this is about or come across it before?
